Title: Comparing small vs large firms' R&D productivity through a dual process perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study explores how small firms approach R&D decisions and how different decision-styles affect R&D productivity. In particular, it addresses how small firms differ from large, complex organizations in their reliance on analytical information tools for decision-making during the introduction of product innovations. The study uses dual-process theory to compare two well-defined styles of making strategic decisions: the analytical and the intuitive style. Hypotheses are derived from the framework and are tested using a sample of Spanish firms for the period 1995 to 2002. Findings suggest that small firms are less analytically oriented than large ones, and firms basing their decisions on analytical information have a lower R&D productivity than those disregarding this type of information.

Title: The impact of mission statements: An empirical analysis from a sensemaking perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Most research to date has analyzed the impact of mission statements from an organizational perspective. This research investigates mission statement perception and impact from an individual perspective. Based on insights derived from the sensemaking literature, we examine the antecedents and impact of management of mission statement meaning (MMSM) by organ-izational members. Data from 1783 employees of three hospitals and one public organization indicates that (a) the level of MMSM is positively related with the degree of strategic supportive attitude and perceived person-organization fit, and (b) perceived colleague pressure and perceived behavioral control are significant determinants of the degree of MMSM.

Title: The consequences of strategic decisions: Firm downsizing and CEO exit
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study examines a CEO's strategic decision to downsize the firm and its effect on his or her own exit over the subsequent course of a five-year business cycle following that structural realignment. Using the 2005 Standard & Poor's 500 firms over the years 1990-2005, statistically significant differences when comparing CEO exits after downsizings to CEOs who did not engage in downsizings were observed. CEO characteristics that increased the tendency to engage in downsizing also increased the probability of the CEO exiting after implementing the action. CEOs with less positional tenure were more likely to exit within five years of the downsizing actions than longer tenured CEOs. As CEO positional tenure increased, the likelihood of early exit from the organization substantially decreased when the downsizing action was executed. Increasing organizational tenure also decreased exit from the firm but not substantially. Short-tenured CEOs are most vulnerable to exiting their position after implanting the strategic decision to downsize, while longer tenured CEOs realize an inoculation against early exit after executing the strategic choice.

Title: Guanxi and Justice perceptions in a hiring context: A comparative study of us and Chinese students
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study addresses fairness surrounding allocation of resources. As different cultures have varied perceptions of what is fair, this study utilized four allocation rules, focusing on the guanxi allocation rule and examined procedural and distributive fairness among 841 American and Chinese students. Findings demonstrated that equity and guanxi allocation rules play an important role in perceptions of justice with regard to the differences between people from individualistic (American) and collectivist (Chinese) nations in the context of human resources. Implications for global hiring and management of employees include the careful use of the most appropriate allocation rule in making business decisions.

Title: Does international strategy matter?
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Implicit in much international business research is the assumption that international strategy matters. In this paper, we directly address this pivotal assumption by applying a novel method for estimating multidimensional fit. This method can handle comprehensive organizational performance models with dozens of main (linear and non-linear) and (bivariate and higher-order) interaction effects, even with relatively small sample sizes. We develop a contingency logic tailored to international business, and anchoring on the role of international strategy. In so doing, we define seven categories of fit. For data about approximately 175 MNEs' subsidiaries we find evidence that supports international business' implicit assumption that international strategy matters.

Title: Deliberate learning in the frontlines of service organizations
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study proposes a conceptual model of deliberate learning process that explains how organizations can capture knowledge embedded in the frontlines of customer interfaces. The model incorporates three inter-related components. First, it proposes a multi-level, multi-phase model of deliberate learning process that includes individual knowledge generation, group knowledge articulation, and unit knowledge codification. Second, workload is proposed as a moderator for the knowledge generation-knowledge articulation transition, while goal congruence is proposed as a moderator for knowledge articulation-knowledge codification transition. Third, the unit performance benefits of deliberate learning are realized by a mediation mechanism involving the three phases of frontline deliberate learning. Using multiple source data from a healthcare services setting, the proposed model is tested. The results suggest that (a) knowledge articulation mediates the effect of knowledge generation on knowledge codification, (b) knowledge codification mediates the effect of knowledge articulation on unit customer satisfaction, revenue, and efficiency, and (c) workload moderates the conversion of knowledge generation to knowledge articulation, and goal congruence moderates the conversion of knowledge articulation to knowledge codification.

Title: Would you like fries with that? Producing and consuming social measures of firm value
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper, we examine why and how institutional entrepreneurs initiate evaluations of firm performance as 'social measures of firm value' along non-financial metrics. Such measures emerge in response to information asymmetries caused by existing measures of firm value that fail to serve the interests of a firm's stakeholders, broadly defined. They then become adopted through an iterative process of production and consumption. We argue that design decisions to employ existing valuation logics, those of quantification and simplification, enable entrepreneurs to measure complex organizational behavior and compare firms along common metrics. These design choices lead to easily understandable and consumable products that facilitate buy-in by stakeholders, firms, and the media. Sufficient buy-in, in turn, gives entrepreneurs the ground to claim the market position of 'information intermediary' in an organizational field. While 'enabling' greater market participation by reducing search costs for all parties in the resource exchange relationship, however, we argue that these measures also carry corresponding 'disabling' consequences that warrant cause for caution. We liken the creation and consumption of these measures to fast-food-filling, convenient, and cheap, but of questionable nutritional value, and potentially harmful if treated as a staple part of a diet.

Title: The impact of exogenous non-economic shocks on the global business environment: A cross-country analysis of the impact of september 11 th on muslim-populated countries
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The risks of operating multinational firms have generally been studied from the perspective of those factors that can be considered endogenous to a particular country or the economic system as a whole. However, global markets are not only subject to these endogenous factors, such as the liability of foreignness or the risk of expropriation, but also a series of exogenous factors, which generally come in the form of a non-economic shock, for instance the rise of global terrorist networks. Unlike the more traditional costs of operating abroad, the impact of non-economic shocks is more complex to recognize and can leave managers with information that lacks clarity or usefulness. When the source of these non-economic shocks can be isolated to an individual or group the event can have a socio-cultural spillover that harms foreign markets which may be linked with that source but had no role in the event's occurrence. Using the terrorist attacks of September 11th 2001 as the empirical context and a novel econometric approach, we find that the costs of operating in Muslim-populated countries increase above and beyond what can be explained by those endogenous economic, political, and social factors. Consistent with our theoretical model, our results suggest that a differential increase in costs of operations in particular foreign markets following an exogenous non-economic shock can be attributed to a manager's likelihood to categorize countries together and link them with the source of the shock.

Title: Synergy through collaboration: A theory of culture's effects
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Increased interest in the importance of collaboration as a means to achieve competitive advantage is leading to widespread rethinking of the practice of operations management. Yet the realization of synergy through such efforts likely will be successful only insofar as collaborating partners overcome different mindsets and corresponding managerial processes. We develop a theory of collaborative synergy - both potential and realized - that rests on concepts drawn from a wide variety of organizational literatures, and we advance a series of propositions regarding both the realization of synergy and the selection of collaboration partners.

Title: Athletes, best friends, and social activists: Modeling multiple paths to organizational identification
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Organizational identification is a function of perceived organizational attractiveness in the eyes of members. While the current theoretical foundation of social identity theory suggests that attractiveness is derived from an organization's distinctiveness and status, this perspective is arguably appropriate to predicting identification among only a narrow subset of organizations and members. It does not account for the considerable role that organizational and individual identity variations play in determining which organizational characteristics members perceive as attractive. In this conceptual paper, I integrate extant work to outline an identity congruence framework of organizational identification highlighting the role that both organizational and member identity play in the identification process generally. I then use this framework to model multiple identity-specific paths to organizational identification by applying to it the lens of identity orientation. Specifically, I outline how variations in organizational and member identity orientation (individualistic, relational, and collectivistic) shape the social comparison content that members draw upon to assess organizational attractiveness. This analysis outlines how and why a wide array of organizations can secure identification and suggests that we may need to significantly broaden our understanding of organizational identification.

Title: Within-group agreement for multi-item scales: Considering interitem correlations
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Within-group agreement indexes support multilevel research on organizational climate, and are often used as a hurdle to justify aggregating individual-level responses to represent a group-level property. Such agreement indexes are derived from a theoretical model involving a group-level construct true score, with simplifying assumptions placed on the between-rater variance. The current paper comments on the role of these assumptions in traditional within-group agreement estimation, and focuses on one particular assumption made in the derivation of multi-item rwg(J): that internal consistency reliability (Cronbach's alpha) for climate scales is zero (LeBreton, James, & Lindell, 2005). We revisit LeBreton et al.'s derivation of the multi-item rwg agreement index, proposing an alternative set of derivations (and modified rwg agreement index) for use with reliable multi-item scales (where Cronbach's alpha > 0). Our goal is to highlight how the theoretical assumption of uncorrelated items on climate scales influences within-group agreement estimation.

Title: Emergence of AIDS policy field in Brazil
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper analyzes the interactions among social actors for the creation of AIDS social field in the context of public policy in Brazil. To achieve this objective, we have mapped individuals and groups, and have investigated the arguments and ideas that supported their institutional entrepreneurial projects to include AIDS in the government agenda. Regarding this aspect, the results of this survey identifies the resources and discourses pursued by some institutional entrepreneurs and the interactions and tensions occurred during the emergence and consolidation of the Aids field in Brazil, focusing specifically the constitution of the National STD-AIDS Program. We had drawn our theoretical argument on the concept of social fields, institutional entrepreneurship, and social skill.

Title: Evaluating the impact of an MBA service-learning course on community service attitudes & behaviors
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Empirical research on business school service-learning courses is quite limited and tends to primarily measure self-reported student reactions to such courses. Even more rare are empirical research studies evaluating outcomes such as knowledge, attitudes, and values. No empirical research could be located examining post-course community service behaviors, a central outcome proposed in the civic engagement theory of service learning. To remedy this gap, this study evaluated the impact of an MBA service-learning course on students' subsequent community service behaviors and attitudes. Community service attitudes and behaviors of students who completed the service-learning course over the last eleven years (n=117) were compared with a matched control group of MBA students (n=95) who did not complete the service-learning course. As was hypothesized, students who completed the MBA service-learning course (1) reported engaging in significantly more community service activities, (2) reported significantly more positive perceptions of the value of community service activities and non-profit arts/cultural organizations to the community, and (3) perceived service-learning opportunities in the MBA program significantly more positively than did students not completing the MBA service-learning course. The implications and limitations of this study are discussed.

Title: On the folly of rewarding A+, while only needing a: The tradeoff between Jacks of all trades and masters of one
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The paper extends the proposition of Kerr's (1975) seminal observations about distorted incentives in organizations. Many organizational reward systems are biased because organizations do not always tie pay closely to performance (Lawler, 1971). The current research theoretically and empirically identifies another important bias of distorted rewards, namely, the folly of rewarding A+, whiling only needing A. Specifically, we propose that because of biased perceptions of generalists, decision makers may overlook their real organizational needs and both recruit and overcompensate redundant personnel. Three studies demonstrate this judgment bias in the context of both corporate HR functions and the National basketball Association (NBA). Study 1 demonstrated that large companies assigned multiple functional duties to their HR specialists and inefficiently placed generalists in their workforce. Study 2 showed that NBA teams failed to tie three point specialists' salaries to their specialized expertise. Survey in Study 3 revealed a similar generalist bias among the basketball fans, who distinctly favored the all-around players even when their team was in need of three point shooters. The fans demonstrated a moderate improvement in their decisions, however, when they evaluated the specialist and the generalist separately.

Title: Who are all these people? Managing expansion, change, and success in the public sector a preliminary assessment
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: How do public agencies manage sudden and rapid infusions of new employees? How rapidly can new employees find mentors, expand their contacts in the agency, and become "effective" when many others are also attempting to integrate themselves concurrently? How does a large public organization socialize large cohorts of new workers? This paper follows the efforts of New York's Office of State Comptroller (OSC) to integrate a large cohort of new auditors and managers hired after a major school finance scandal in 2005. Using longitudinal, ego-centric network data we study the advice, information, friendship, and role model networks 22 auditors and 15 promoted managers created during their first year on the job in order to identify factors determining the effective acquisition of task-relevant and organizational information and to develop strategies to promote successful integration. In addition, we follow the networks of 6 experienced managers as a comparison group. This study presents preliminary findings based on three of the four waves of data collection. We have found clear differentiation in the structure of the four types of networks. Each has a characteristic structure that reflects differentiation in purpose of the networks. These differences are not related to gender. We have also found that some efforts by OSC to proactively shape the structure of these four networks have not been instantiated in the structure of the resulting ego-nets. The paper concludes with a discussion of implications for public managers.

Title: The adoption of a foreign group subsidiary: An institutional multiplicity perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Drawing on institutional theory and using the context of MNCs, this study developed a new framework to explore the multiple institutional pressures faced by MNC subsidiaries in their decision to adopt a foreign group subsidiary in an emerging economy. We distinguished between coercive and mimetic isomorphism mechanisms and discriminated between the origins of imitation pressures. The study highlighted the coercive isomorphic pressures from local government inducement, the mimetic isomorphic influences from global peers, and most important of all, the critical roles of an MNC¡̄s local business group partners in the interorganizational imitation process. It points to the importance of these key institutional isomorphic influences on the adoption of an organizational practice by MNCs operating in emerging economies, which is not only interesting from an academic perspective, but also has important practitioner implications.

Title: Words of action: The centrist and pragmatic discourse of sustainable development reporting
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Purpose - This paper aims to examine language use and (re)presentations within the business context around the concept of sustainable development. In doing this we consider how a representation of a phenomena constructs our understanding of that phenomena and how context, in terms of a business association for sustainable development, is important in this construction process. We argue that such representations are constitutive of the way that business has come to 'know' and 'do' sustainable development and these constrain and enable particular actions and developments. Design/methodology/approach - Using a New Zealand-based study, this study draws on two main sources of materials: a corpus of written and presentational materials produced by a business association and eight of its members' first publicly available triple bottom line reports. The coding and analytic process involved a close interpretive examination of the documents to uncover meanings rather than document the volume of disclosure. The content of the reports and pronouncements is framed and analysed within a wider paradigmatic debate on sustainable development. Findings - The business association and its members' reports are shown to present a pragmatic and middle-way discourse on business and the environment. Through the use of rhetorical claims to pragmatism and action, the discourse suggests businesses are "doing sustainability". The association and its members are shown to present a narrow, largely economic and instrumental approach to the natural environment. Such a discourse we argue runs contrary to claims of reform and transformation, and instead reinforces the status quo of traditional interests of business-as-usual over the natural environment. Originality/value - This paper will be of value to researchers interested in business and sustainable development. By taking an interpretive approach and extending the analysis to a business association, we illustrate the ideological role communication plays in the organised construction of a dominant and potentially unassailable approach to the natural environment. Title: Is experience valuable in international strategic alliances
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study investigates whether firms benefit from accumulation of prior experiences in non-equity involved international strategic alliances (ISAs). Previous studies on the issue of experiential learning in the domain of international alliances have mostly focused on equity involved joint venture, while non-equity involved alliance, the other type of international cooperations, is conversely left under researched about its experience effect. Given the mixed evidences of experience effect in international joint ventures, investigating the experience issue against non-equity alliances will yield a new insight on this topic. In contrast to previous studies most of which simply concentrate on quantity increase of alliance experience to address its benefits, we visit the issue with a finer picture, asking the question that if experience similarity enhances firm performance, and further, under what condition that such specific learning most influential. With 629 non-equity involved international alliances formed by US firms, our results basically confirm the benefits of prior experiences in ISAs. Experience in general, and that specific to activity type and partner¡s country are documented beneficial. However, such experiential learning is not equivalent which effect is greatly moderated by the level of alliance complexity. Experiences under great uncertainty, in terms of cooperations on techniques or/and with partners from developing countries, are found specifically imperative for alliance partnering firms. We derive the above argument from both ex ante market¡s evaluation of alliance announcement and ex post firm¡s operating performance. Findings from this research may help further our understanding on the issue of inter-firm experiential learning in the domain of international alliances.

Title: Board information advantage: A study of board capital and absorptive capacity
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study examines how board capital and absorptive capacity improve board strategic task performance. It uses an argument from a recent information processing model, which advocates using unique information in a diverse group. A distinction between static and dynamic resources is made where the static dimension addresses board capital and the dynamic one the absorptive capacity. Board capital is discussed in terms of information diversity, while absorptive capacity in terms of three practices that tap unique information. Structural Equation Modeling is applied with survey data collected in years 2003 and 2005. The results suggest different effects of board capital and absorptive capacity on board strategic task performance. Board capital seems to enhance the board's future strategic task performance, while absorptive capacity the board's current strategic task performance.

Title: Operations and maintenance practices and their impact on power plant performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The aim of the study was to examine the impact of Operations and Maintenance (O&M) practices, individually and collectively, on power plant performance. Data were collected from more than 100 power plants in Australia and Malaysia. The reliability and validity (content, construct, and criterion) of the practice and performance measures were evaluated. Our study showed that the relationship between O&M practices and plant performance is significant and positive in a cross-sectional sense. Both people-oriented "soft" as well technically-oriented as "hard" practices were found to be positive and significant predictors of plant performance. This is consistent with literature on socio-technical systems theory that both "soft" and "hard" practices are required to complement each other to produce and sustain high performance. Among the practices, executive commitment and TPM-orientation are the strongest significant predictors of plant performance. Our findings also highlight the impact of maintenance practices on plant performance compared to other practices such as long-term planning, customer focus, knowledge management, and employee involvement. Based on our study we conclude that Total Quality Management (TQM) and maintenance philosophies are sources of sustainable competitive advantage in the power generation sector.

Title: The contingent value of political ties in evolving environments: Exit of domestic firms following competitive foreign entry
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper evaluates the impact of managerial ties to political agencies on domestic firms' exit decisions in response to foreign firms' entry into evolving markets. We propose that political ties retain its value on domestic firms' exit in evolving environment, and the impact varies with the nature of ties, firm strategy and environmental factors. We study the exit decisions of a sample of TV manufacturing firms following the sudden and substantial entry of multinationals in the evolving Chinese economy from 1993 to 2003. Results show that (1) political ties remain an important influence on domestic firms' exit following substantial foreign entry, reducing firms' likelihood of dissolution, and increasing their likelihood of being acquired; (2) political ties increase the risk of firms being acquired immediately following foreign entry, and reduce dissolution risks in the longer term; and (3) the value of these ties varies over time, with the exact nature of the variation depending on contextual factors and types of ties and strategy.

Title: Person-centered work environments in health care: Preliminary test of a theoretical framework
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Much attention has been paid in recent years to improving the quality of care patients receive in the hospital. Many experts, including the Institute of Medicine, are now starting to propose that the working environment for health care staff has an important impact on the care and safety of patients, through its impact on staff morale and commitment (Page, 2004). The present study tested a theoretical framework that proposes three person-centered dimensions in the health care work environment are necessary for positive outcomes: (1) a climate for patient-centered care; (2) a climate for continuous quality improvement; and (3) a benevolent ethical climate. A work environment that includes higher levels of these climates is hypothesized to predict positive outcomes for staff, such as commitment, and engagement, and as well, positive outcomes for patients, such as patient safety. The model proposes that positive psychological states among care providers mediate relationships between the work environment and outcomes. As a preliminary test of the model, survey data from 252 clinical care providers working in a large urban hospital were analyzed. Structural equations modeling analyses found partial support for the model, in that care providers' psychological safety partially mediated the relationships between the work environment and care provider commitment. Direct relationships also existed between some of the work environment climates and care provider well-being and patient safety outcomes. Implications and limitations are discussed.

Title: Money and fame: Vividness effects in the National Basketball Association
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In his widely reprinted article "On the Folly of Rewarding A, While Hoping for B", Kerr (1975) argued that vividness was one of the major reasons for distorted rewards. Using both archival and survey data, the present paper directly tests Kerr's proposal by investigating whether, how and why highly visible behaviors are over-rewarded and less visible, but at least equally important behaviors are under-rewarded. The National Basketball Association (NBA) was chosen as the domain of this study because scoring is particularly vivid. In the NBA, both non-scoring performance and scoring performance are critical for winning games (Chatterjee, Campbell & Wiseman, 1994; Hofler & Payne, 2004). However, findings from four studies demonstrated that the scoring performance of NBA players was weighed more heavily than their non-scoring performance because of its vividness. Scorers were rewarded with higher salaries and received more support in the NBA All-Star balloting than defenders, even though they might not necessarily make more contribution than their teammates. This pattern of findings suggests that the vividness effect may lead to pronounced differences in people's judgments especially when they are overwhelmed with abundant real-world information with similar validity.

Title: Transferability of the venture capital model to the corporate venture unit context
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: While recent literature has advocated the transfer of venture capital (VC) practices and structures to corporate venture (CV) units, the wisdom of this advice has not been subject to rigorous empirical scrutiny. We test the implications of the VC model for CV unit performance using a longitudinal database (combining survey, archival and survival data) on 95 CV units. Overall, adopting central elements the VC model was associated with higher CV unit performance. Critically, however, different elements of the VC model predicted strategic versus financial performance in CV units - the impact on financial dimensions of performance also being somewhat more pronounced. Specifically, horizontal autonomy, communication with the VC community, and relatedness of investments each positively influence the strategic performance of the CV unit. Likewise, behaving like a VC in terms of compensation, syndication centrality and relatedness of investments (inverted U shape) also positively influences the financial performance of the CV unit. In addition, survival of the CV unit was strongly associated with adopting the VC model (mediated, in part, by the enhanced performance of the CV unit when adopting the VC model).

Title: CEO dismissal: The role of investment analysts as an external control mechanism
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: While poor performance and internal agency conditions (e.g., board power and CEO power) have been shown to be predictors of CEO dismissal, little is known about the role of the firm's external constituents in CEO dismissal. In this study, we argue that investment analysts, through their reports and ratings, serve an important external monitoring role over corporate behavior. Therefore, we expect that investment analysts can influence the board's evaluation of the firm and its leadership. We find that board dismissal of the CEO occurs more frequently for firms with more negative investment analyst ratings, providing strong support for their external monitoring role.

Title: Strawman: The reconfiguration of Max Weber in management textbooks and why it matters
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: History has never figured prominently in conventional management textbooks, and when it is covered its superficial treatment largely goes unquestioned by instructors and students. To illustrate, this paper analyses the representation of Max Weber in management texts. Using a set of Foucauldian methods we find their representation of Weber over the past 30 years to be highly dubious, a reflection of a peculiar perspective that emerged in the middle of the 20th century, and driven more by a desire to justify the latest 'one best way' than an accurate reflection of anything that Weber actually said. We reflect on the negative consequences of this sort of history for management education and offer some ideas as to how such a problematic treatment of history could be overcome.

Title: Valuation biases and the persistence of international joint ventures
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Investors often retain their initial set-up of an international joint venture (IJV) even when more beneficial alternatives have emerged. Such persistence appears inconsistent with rational decision-making. We analyze this persistence to advance the theoretical analysis of strategic decisions in international business with a focus on switches of ownership modes. More specifically, we propose a model that explains how cognitive biases may affect managerial valuations and thus decision-making regarding IJVs.

Title: Abusive behavior: Trickle-down effects beyond the dyad
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Much of the abusive supervision research has focused on the dyad when examining the effects of abusive leader behavior on employee outcomes. Extending this research, we tested a trickle-down model with a sample of 189 matched triads from three hierarchical levels (managers, supervisors, and employees). Our results indicated support for our trickle-down model in that manager abusive behavior not only negatively impacted supervisor outcomes but negatively influenced employees two hierarchical levels below the managers. The effects of manager abusive behavior on supervisor outcomes were mediated by cynicism toward the manager and supervisor abusive behavior mediated the effects of manager abusive behavior on employee outcomes.

Title: Diversity and conflict in teams: A faultline model perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Although diversity in traditional as well virtual teams has received much attention in past two decades, extant prior diversity research has yielded inconsistent results. In this paper, we present an integrated model of the relationships between different types of diversity and different types of conflict. Drawing from conceptual work on team faultlines, we suggest that diversity shapes conflict but the relationship has subtleties. Using data from twenty student teams across three time periods, we found that diversity drives conflict, but the relationship is often curvilinear. We also found that different types of diversity have varying impacts on different types of conflicts. Overall, these patterns suggest a complex relationship between team diversity and team conflict.

Title: Change capabilities or cynicism? How change experience influences employee reactions
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The aim of this paper is to explore how experience with organizational change influences employee reactions to change. An increasing rate and frequency of organizational change processes can lead to change fatigue and cynicism, but there is also some evidence that experience with change can generate more positive reactions to change. Drawing on four different studies of reactions to planned change, we probe how reactions to change are affected by previous experience with change. Our findings suggest that employees with limited change experience react stronger, more emotionally, and more actively to planned change as compared with employees that have been through many change processes. As organizational members gain experience with large-scale planned change, they use less effort to resist change and show more loyal but also more passive reactions to change. While we argue that experience with planned change can contribute in developing change capabilities and hence ultimately affect an organization's capacity for change, this requires that past experiences are positive and that managers have developed structural, procedural and interpersonal change management capabilities.

Title: Research in emerging economies: Reading small type in dim light in a speeding train?
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Emerging economies have increasingly been acknowledged as a research field with immense potential. At the same time, the fact remains that unless the contextual differences with developed economies are accounted for, researchers could misspecify research designs. The pace of evolution of 'context' in emerging economies, coupled with 'weak signals' emanating from sparsely distributed data points calls for the primacy of idiographic explanations, such as those afforded by the case study method. As case research links observations, experiences and underlying mechanisms, it allows the researcher to tackle problems associated with continuous transformation of institutional arrangements in emerging economies. In contrast, a researcher employing conventional survey research in such settings may not be alert to either the presence of unfamiliar contingencies or the operation of hitherto dormant mechanisms, resulting in low 'validity.' Furthermore, such survey research would have low 'reliability' due to low statistical power of the significance tests. With its potential for higher validity and higher reliability under such circumstances, we argue that the case study method is a more appropriate and powerful tool to capture rich data for theory building in emerging economies.

Title: Identity and reflexivity in research on women accountants
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper reviews research into the scarcity of women at the highest levels of accountancy. We argue that only by integrating the different stories can we fully understand the scarcity of women in all its complexity and insert it into the broader problematic of the professional's identity. Women's representation is not solely an issue relating to women, since stereotyped roles perpetuated at the social and organisational levels influence both male and female accountant identities. Moreover, raising the issue of the identity of the accountant leads us to raise the issue of the identity of the researcher. By exploring research designs, we elaborate on the nature of reflexivity in research, in particular on the interplay among different levels of interpretation (description, explanation, prediction and prescription, as described by Ahrens and Chapman, 2006) that is alternately ignored, claimed or rejected by accounting scholars addressing gender issues.

Title: Towards culture-sensitive theories of the work-family interface
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Due to societal trends, managing the work-family interface has become an increasingly challenging task for employees in virtually every nation. However, prior studies of this interface have mostly tested U.S.- based theories using U.S. samples. The construct of societal or national culture, which seems likely to shape individuals' experiences of the work-family interface, has been generally unacknowledged in theories and research in the work-family literature. In this article, we offer guidelines for the development of culture-sensitive theories of work-family phenomena and for research to test such theories as they are developed. First, we review the few prior research attempts that have incorporated cultural considerations in some manner and identify cultural dimensions that are likely to influence the work-family interface. Next, we demonstrate how selected cultural dimensions may be incorporated into theories of work-family conflict and enrichment, two constructs that represent the negative and positive side of the work-family interface respectively, to make these theories more culture-sensitive. Finally, we offer an ambitious agenda for future theory and research to increase understanding of cultural influences on the work-family interface.

Title: Alliance partner diversity and biotech firms' exit: Differing effects on dissoluion vs. divestment
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper focuses on the role that alliance portfolio diversity (APD) plays in the probability of small high-tech firms' exit. It contributes to the research in strategy and entrepreneurship by developing finer-grained theoretical arguments in order to explain whether and why APD would differently determine firms' exit by dissolution vs. divestment. Alliance portfolio diversity is considered as a strategic instrument that firms may use either to avoid involuntary dissolution (decreasing the probability of exit) or to realize a possibility of divestment (increasing the probability of exit). Empirical findings from French biotechnology industry (1994-2002) show that APD increases the risk of dissolution, while the relation is curvilinear (inverted U-shaped) in the case of divestment.

Title: Does noblesse oblige? The effects of firm reputation and celebrity on earnings surprises and investors' reactions
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: We examine the effects of firm reputation and celebrity on 1) the likelihood that a firm generates a positive or negative earnings surprise, and 2) how investors react to positive and negative surprises when they occur. We find that firms endowed with high reputation and celebrity status receive greater market rewards for positive surprises and fewer market penalties for negative surprises relative to firms that do not possess these intangible assets. In addition, the market reacts more positively to positive surprises by celebrity firms than to positive surprises by high reputation firms. We contribute to organizational research and management practice by highlighting how a firm's specific endowment of intangible assets can lead to the possibility of non-conforming behavior and generate asymmetric evaluations of this behavior in the marketplace.

Title: Influence of individual differences on the growth of leadership efficacy over time
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: I explore the connections between intelligence, personality, leadership efficacy, and leadership behaviors drawing from Bandura's (1997) framework of social cognitive theory and using longitudinal data analysis with random coefficient modeling (Bliese & Ployhart, 2002). I propose that general mental ability and individual personality in terms of the Five Factor Model of personality (Costa & McRae, 1992; Hogan, 1991) may be important antecedents of the development of leadership efficacy in team members, both with respect to the initial state of leadership efficacy at the beginning of a team's task and how it changes over time. Based on a sample of 198 participants in 40 MBA teams engaged in a four-day business simulation, my findings indicated that personal leadership efficacy beliefs were positively related to others' assessments of leadership behaviors. Also, I found that leadership efficacy changes within individuals in a meaningful way over time; intelligence and extraversion were significant predictors of individuals' initial leadership efficacy estimates; and emotional stability was a significant predictor of the change in leadership efficacy over time (i.e., slope).

Title: Who created China's household farms and township-village enterprises: The conscious few or the ignorant many?
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Mainstream theories on institutional change emphasise political leadership, ideology framing, planned mobilisation and formal organising. Such theories, increasingly popular in Western literature though, are ill-prepared to account for the creation of China's household farms and township-village enterprises in the reform era. Documented evidences reveal that the two organisations are built not by the few shining elites, nor by formally organised collectives, but by millions of ignorant farmers via massive local experimentation that is spontaneous, unorganised, leaderless, nonideological and apolitical. The case of the Chinese farmers thus challenges some hidden assumptions of the 'emerging consensus', or rather the conventional wisdom, in actor-centred institutional theorising, and calls for a more balanced research agenda that is adequately sensitive to institutional differences and significantly inclusive to embrace non-elite agency.

Title: The effects of teacher human and social capital on student performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: We investigated the role of teacher human and social capital on growth in student performance with a sample of 1,020 teachers organized into 240 grade teams. We find that teacher human capital and some indicators of teacher social capital are important predictors of student improvement. Team-level experience, and team social capital, measured by horizontal and vertical intensity of communication, are also significant predictors of student performance improvement. We provide some evidence that team-level indicators of social capital moderate the impact of teacher skill on student performance. Implications for theory, research, and policy are discussed.

Title: Patent sharks and the sustainability of value destruction strategies
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Patent sharks (a.k.a. patent trolls) appropriate innovation rents by threatening to patent-block other players' R&D-related value creation. Scholars have identified two inefficiencies in legal practise (patentee-friendly injunctions and the granting of excessive damage awards) as drivers of these 'destructive' strategies, suggesting that policy changes can suppress the shark business in the future. Modelling interactions between sharks and manufacturers within a biform game, we show formally that the shark problem is more subtle from a theoretical managerial perspective and sustainable to policy changes in part. Patent extortion will remain a viable strategy in technologically crowded industries when sharks choose patents on inventions that (1) can be invented around rather easily before infringement, but (2) are sufficiently sophisticated to be upheld in court and (3) create significant mid-term switching costs for manufacturers after infringement. By presenting original data on all publicly reported cases of patent shark attacks, we provide empirical indications a) that different sharking strategies as predicted by theory exist in practise and b) that a significant share of professional shark firms already pursue strategies that are likely to remain sustainable after legal changes. We discuss implications for management theory in the area of innovation strategy and business strategy more broadly.

Title: Networking, planning, and the effect of political institutions on new venture survival
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Entrepreneurs constitute a key economic driving force for many emerging economies. In this paper, we explore how political environments affect entrepreneurial processes and outcomes in firms. We present a theory that explains how political turmoil influences entrepreneurial networking and moderates planning processes. We test this theory using a sample of 730 new ventures in Colombia from 1997-2001. This paper directs attention to the primary influence of political institutions in emerging economies on entrepreneurial processes and outcomes and highlights the need for governments to make institutional changes that will aid in the emergence and growth of entrepreneurial organizations.

Title: ME too or not me? The influence of the structure of competition on mimetic market entry
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper analyzes how the wider "structure of competition" that a firm finds itself in - in terms of who competes with whom in what segments within an industry - influences its behavior. Specifically, we use this notion to examine how a firm's decision to enter mimetically into a new market depends on the extent to which its competitors compete with each other. We argue that a firm is especially inclined to imitate its direct competitors if its rivals also compete directly with each other, out of a fear to become "the odd one out." This inclination is even stronger if the firm's rivals are engaged in multimarket competition with each other, which leads to non-aggressive behavior due to mutual forbearance. In contrast, a firm tends to shy away from following their competitors' market entry moves if these companies have an equivalent dependence on the segments they operate in, since this sets the stage for aggressive, cut-throat competition; in this case, firms are happy "to be left behind." We test our hypotheses in two distinct contexts, in both cases capturing the full population of firms in the industry: Chinese drug producers' entry into new product markets during the period 1993-2001 and Taiwanese PC hardware manufacturers' entry into new geographic markets in China during the period 1999-2005. We find strong support for our predictions in both contexts. Overall, the results highlight how a firm's (mimetic) behavior not only depends on how it relates to its competitors, but also on how these competitors relate towards each other. We discuss how future research might extend the concept of the structure of competition and how it might be applied to other aspects of organizational behavior.

Title: An empirical invesigation of human capital and performance: NCAA men's basketball teams
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Empirical work in strategic human resource management has tended to focus solely on the relationship between human resource practices and firm performance. In this study we introduce a revisionist approach to shift the focus of strategic human resource management to the human resource pool (KSAs) to examine the influence that the human resource has on firm performance (Harris & McMahan, 2007). Additionally, this study introduces a temporal element we call overlapping tenure. This variable is measured by the amount of time people have worked together toward common performance outcomes. Findings include a positive relationship between both employees and managers knowledge, skills, and abilities and firm performance. Also, employees overlapping tenure and the overlapping tenure of employees with their manager are positively related to firm performance. Lastly, the interaction between employees knowledge, skills, and abilities and employees overlapping tenure has a positive relationship with firm performance.

Title: Safety and organizational design factors: Decentralization, alignment, and influence
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study examines the relationship between three design attributes - decentralization, alignment, influence - and organizational-level safety outcomes. We assessed safety-related practices embedded as part of organizational design at 54 organizations through a survey of top-level managers. We used injury reports to measure each organization's safety record. Results extend the safety literature by examining organizational design factors impacting safety outcomes, and by providing evidence that two organizational design constructs, decentralization and alignment, help reduce overall organizational injuries.

Title: Rolesharing in the managerial workplace: Managers' perceptions of their roles and of external consultants' helpfulness in strategy projects
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper provides a joint assessment of managers' perceptions of their roles and of the helpfulness of consultants in supporting these roles in the context of strategy projects. Drawing on the extant literature on managerial role perception and on consultants' roles, we test the relative importance and the antecedents of Mintzberg's managerial roles, using a sample of 365 managers. The results indicate that managers emphasize the leader and entrepreneur roles. They perceive consultants to be most helpful in the execution of the monitor and entrepreneur roles. We find that individual-level factors such as gender, age, experience, and professional background are most important for explaining managerial role perception.

Title: Putting a value on openness: The effect of product source code releases on the market value of firms
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study examines the effect of opening up the innovation process on the market value of firms. Using the example of firms releasing proprietary software as open source in a sample of 30 software companies in the time span from 1999 to 2007, I find that market valuation is strongly influenced by the business model firms choose to generate and appropriate value. The non-existence of an explicit revenue model is punished by the capital market while firms whose efforts include an explicit revenue model achieve a premium on their stock price, confirming the potential for value-creation of open innovation efforts.

Title: Growth and switching options in foreign direct investment
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: A real options view of foreign direct investments (FDI) has shed light in new directions on why and how firms invest internationally under unanticipated changes in macroeconomic factors. Although there is increasing interest over multinational corporation (MNC) flexibility under uncertainty, the current status of research is mixed. In this research, we endeavor to locate possible solutions for inconclusive past research. There are two different views on the real options value of international investments. One is the growth options view, noting that FDI carry great growth potential through foothold investments within host countries. Through such investments, MNCs can adapt to local environment in incremental ways over time. On the other hand, the switching options view indicates that FDI can flexibly shift value chain activities across countries under unanticipated fluctuations in exchange rate and/or demand across countries. It is important to note that the two views provide conflicting predictions on the same attributes of multinationality. For example, minority ownership increases growth options value, while majority or whole ownership increases switching options value. In addition, broader operations across many countries have been associated with switching options value, while deeper operations in a given country associated with growth options value. Without controlling for breadth of operations and level of ownership, the real options value of international investments can lead to inconclusive results by canceling out the value embedded in one type over another. This research addresses this issue. Based on a sample of Korean manufacturing firms, we find that during the uncertainty period of the Korean economic crisis (characterized by high exchange rate volatility), firms¡̄ international investments provided them with switching options rather than growth options. International investments were associated with growth options during pre-crisis periods, however.

Title: Do stakeholders detect corporate social performance signals?
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study seeks to examine the mechanism by which a corporation's use of philanthropy might affect its reputation for CSP, as well as the public's awareness of a firm's CSP efforts. We propose and test a model relating corporate philanthropy and foundations to awareness of and evaluations of firm social performance. We use signal detection theory to model size and scope of philanthropy on perceptions and awareness of CSP. We also include domestic v. foreign firms, to investigate whether the liability of foreignness extends to perceptions and awareness of CSP. We find that the relationships are more perplexing than others have proposed. Our contention that corporate philanthropy is a complex variable is upheld and we propose avenues for future research.

Title: International knowledge and the growth(s) of the firm
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Previous research suggests that small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) can acquire new knowledge when operating and in international markets and, thereby, enrich their limited resource base. In this study, we examine the growth implications of this new knowledge. Building on the internationalization literature, the knowledge based view (KBV) and Penrose's theory of the growth of the firm we propose that the new knowledge is a malleable resource enhancing different growth outcomes. Our results indicate that the accumulated experiential knowledge in international markets contributes to a firm's growth advantage in international markets and to further internationalization. In addition, the study shows that it provides the basis for entrepreneurial actions such as venturing into new markets and research new international customers. However, our results also suggest that this new knowledge has no, or very little, effect on SME growth in the domestic market.

Title: Considering context in team diversity research: A meta-analytic review
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Integrating both macro and micro theoretical perspectives, we conducted a meta-analysis examining the role of contextual factors in team diversity research. Using data from 7,575 teams across 32 studies conducted in organizational settings, we examined whether contextual factors at multiple levels including industry, occupation and team levels influenced the performance outcomes of relations-oriented and task-oriented diversity. Our findings revealed that although the direct effects of relations-oriented and task-oriented diversity on performance were significant, these effects were small and, after accounting for industry, occupational, and team-level contextual moderators, tripled in size. We discuss the theoretical and practical implications of these findings.
Index Keywords: Context; Contextual factors; Meta-analysis; Multiple levels; Organizational setting; Performance outcome; Team diversity; Team performance; Factor analysis

Title: Balancing exploitation and exploration: Organizational antecedents and performance effects of ambidexterity
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In the present study, we investigate the performance effects and organizational antecedents of ambidexterity defined as the capacity to simultaneously exploit established businesses and explore new opportunities. Building on the organization and innovation literature, we argue that ambidexterity is positively related to organizational performance. Further, we suggest that both, (a) the creation of a high performance organizational context (contextual ambi-dexterity) and (b) the organizational partitioning and targeted integration of exploitative and explorative tasks (structural ambidexterity) are adequate organizational approaches to become ambidextrous. Data collected from 284 medium-sized and large organizations support our hypotheses.

Title: Entrepreneur role prototypes and role identity in the U.S., China, and Taiwan
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This multi-part study investigates entrepreneurial motivation in three nations from a role-based identity perspective in the U.S., China, and Taiwan, examining how an aspired entrepreneur role identity affects nascent opportunity discovery and exploitation decisions as individuals move toward being an entrepreneur. In an initial two-step study designed to assess social views of entrepreneur role, we inductively generated a comprehensive list of attributes associated with this role in each country. Drawing on those results, an independent sample of 471 individuals in the three countries assessed the extent to which these attributes fit their image of entrepreneurs. While several similarities existed in social views of the prototypical entrepreneur role, there were also meaningful differences, and the magnitude of endorsement of prototypical elements was significantly different across the three countries. We then conducted a second study in the three countries (n = 597) to extend the ideas and results from the first study to develop and validate a measure of aspired entrepreneur identity and assess its ability to predict nascent entrepreneurial behaviors of opportunity discovery, exploitation, and behavioral commitment. In all three settings, strength of aspired entrepreneurial identity was significantly associated with the extent to which the individual's self-description fit personally normative views of the entrepreneurial role. Identity strength was predictive of nascent entrepreneurial behaviors in all three nations. Structural equation modeling indicated that the entrepreneur identity measure we developed was equivalent across the three settings. Implications of the results for entrepreneurship theory were discussed.
Index Keywords: Cross-cultural; Entrepreneur; Entrepreneurial behavior; Identity; Role-based; Structural equation modeling

Title: The birth and death of sensegiving spirals: Searching for meaning during Hong Kong's SARS outbreak
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This is an exploratory study on sensegiving spirals using a case study of the SARS epidemic in Hong Kong in 2003. While knowledge on sensegiving cumulates, little is known about the interactive and continuous nature of sensegiving. To gain insight into this, we studied sensegiving spirals, or deviation-amplifying loops in which the cyclic relationship among two or more parties' sensegiving efforts builds upon itself. Our study provided a rich account regarding how sensegiving spirals manifest, including external contextual factors and internal leader and stakeholder factors that contribute to its birth, life and death.

Title: Measuring idiosyncratic work arrangements: Development and validation of the ex-post I-deals scale
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Idiosyncratic deals are mutually beneficial, personalized agreements of a nonstandard nature that are negotiated between individual employees and their employers. The purpose of the current research was to develop and validate a measure of ex-post idiosyncratic deals using two studies. Study 1 tests the dimensionality of the i-deals construct. Results of this study support a five-factor measure of i-deals. These factors include: general propensity for i-deals, task and work responsibilities, financial incentives, scheduling flexibility, and location flexibility. Study 2 further validates the measure by demonstrating discriminate and convergent validity with several external variables including: perceived organizational support, social exchange perceptions, organizational justice, psychological contract breach, perceived supervisor support, leader-member exchange, political skill, organizational politics, job leisure conflict, organizational commitment, and job satisfaction. Limitations, implications, and directions for future research are discussed.

Title: First decade of Orm: Trends in design, measurement, and data-analysis topics
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: We conducted a content analysis of the 193 articles published in the first 10 volumes (1998-2007) of Organizational Research Methods (ORM). To do so, we created the most comprehensive research methods taxonomy available to date, including quantitative and qualitative approaches, to categorize design, measurement, and data-analysis topics. Over the 10-year period, the most popular quantitative topics are surveys, temporal issues, and electronic/Web research (design), validity, reliability, and level of analysis of the dependent variable (measurement), and multiple regression/correlation, structural equation modeling, and multilevel research (analysis). The most popular qualitative topics are interpretive, policy capturing, and action research (design), surveys and reliability (measurement), and interpretive, policy capturing, and content analysis (analysis). Results also show several upward trends in the attention devoted to topics such as surveys and electronic/Web research, interpretive, and action research (design), level of analysis of the dependent variable and validity (measurement), and multilevel research (analysis). These results show similarities but also notable differences in relation to previously published reviews of the research methods that are reported in substantive journals. Finally, we compared the topics published in ORM with the methodological tools needed to test influential theories in the organizational sciences. We discuss implications for training doctoral students, re-tooling researchers, future research on methodology, the advancement of the organizational sciences, and the extent to which ORM is fulfilling its mission.

Title: Conformity for legitimacy: A perspective from the learning model of firm risk-taking
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: To extend the understanding of why organizations conform to institutional pressures for legitimacy, in this study, we explore if and how a learning model of risk-taking can help us to understand the cognitive underpinnings of organizational conformity for legitimacy. Based on the neo-institutional theory and the learning model of risk taking, we hypothesize that a firm is more or less likely to conform to prevailing institutional pressures depending on how firms perceive the risks associated to conformity under performance gains or losses. We also hypothesize that a firm¡s status in a hierarchical structure can further moderate this process. We test these hypotheses using a sample of U.S. venture capital firms from 1990-2003. Our results show that a firm is more likely to conform to prevailing practices and norms in the area of both gains and losses, and that the conformity tendency is stronger in the area of losses than in the area of gains. We also find that a firm¡s status significantly moderates this process. We discuss the implications of these results on theories of conformity for legitimacy, status and firm risk-taking.

Title: Multinational firm knowledge, use of expatriates and foreign subsidiary performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study examines the relationship between a multinational firm's technological and marketing knowledge, its expatriate staffing practices, and the performance of its foreign subsidiaries. Expatriates are conceptualized as playing a key role in facilitating the transfer and redeployment of a parent firm's knowledge to its subsidiary. Our analysis of 3,848 Japanese subsidiaries indicates that the expatriate ratio: (1) positively moderates the effect of a parent's technological knowledge on subsidiary performance in the short term, and (2) negatively moderates the impact of the parent firm's marketing knowledge on subsidiary performance in the medium term, but not in the short term. We also find that expatriates' influence on knowledge transfer disappears over the long term, illustrating the temporal nature of knowledge transfer.

Title: Client and consultant interaction: Capturing social practices of professional service production
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The interaction between clients and consultants during consulting projects is essential for their success and is, consequently, of critical importance for the long-term survival of con-sulting companies. Since the exchange of clients and consultants is embedded in ongoing social practices, it is essential to identify and analyse these practices in order to explain and design the client-consultant relationship. We integrate three main theoretical perspectives or models on the client-consultant interaction - the expert model, the critical model and the social learning model - to develop an empirically grounded theory on this issue. Based on the investigation of seven consultancy projects within an international technical consulting firm, we identify three major practices that characterize the client-consultant interaction - shaping impressions, problem-solving, and negotiating expectations - and discuss their char-acteristics, activities, and contingencies.

Title: The social construction of the positive link between Corporate Social and Financial Performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper investigates the relationship between Corporate Social Performance (CSP) and Financial Performance (FP) as a deliberate social and cognitive construction. We argue that the demonstration of a positive CSP-FP relationship is a business problem for managers developing the markets for virtue because their legitimacy is closely associated to the belief that 'social responsibility pays'. Accordingly, we develop a framework explaining how institutional processes can enact a positive CSP-FP relationship that may eventually be self-realized.

Title: Storming legitimacy barriers: Attention and favorability during emergence of the American film industry
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The emergence of new industries has remained conceptually and empirically problematic, particularly in terms of overcoming what Aldrich and Fiol (1994) characterize as the legitimacy barriers to emergence. Ecological theory suggests legitimacy is a mere spillover of increasing density; social movement theory suggests the need for organized collective action to overcome legitimacy barriers. We suggest a middle course. The experience that firms gain in field-relevant activity, as well as the concentration of ties that develop among those firms, generates field-level capacity to storm the barriers of cognitive and socio-political legitimacy, creating attention and favorability assessments for the new forms of activity.

Title: Product/service quality and emotional aspect of customer satisfaction
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper studies the links between quality and consumers' emotions and eventually with their satisfaction. There is mounting evidence that, while quality evaluation may be strictly cognitive, satisfaction gauges customers' emotions towards the product/service provider's performance. Existing approaches used in measuring quality have certain limitations. This study introduces two components of total quality structure - quality of design and quality of conformance - for analysis of link between quality and customer emotions. The results show that there is a significant relationship between possible combinations of two quality dimensions and customers' affective responses in terms of their valence and intensity. Important managerial implications are discussed.

Title: The black-box deciphered: A meta-analysis of team diversity conflict and team performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this study, we perform a meta-analysis of the relationships between team diversity, conflict, and team outcomes (performance and morale). Using a sample of over 20,000 teams across 175 studies, we find that, on average, the association of team member diversity and team conflict is weak, but that the strongest, positive, association is the one between task conflicts and team member diversity on informational characteristics. We also find that task-, relationship-, and process conflicts are negatively associated with team member morale and team performance but that task conflicts under specific conditions, including high task complexity, are positively related with performance.

Title: Betting on the horse or the Jockey: The impact of expertise on angel investing
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Contradictory results have left open the question as to whether angels place more weight on the strength of the opportunity or on the entrepreneur and the new venture team when they evaluate the funding potential of a new venture. Three limitations of prior research designs likely led to the contradictory results so this study addresses those by studying angels' decision making in one of the largest angel investment networks in the U.S., examining decision making at two different stages of the angel screening process and incorporating factors that likely account for differences among angels. Our results indicate that angels place more weight on the strength of the opportunity versus the entrepreneur and the NVT in the screening stage of the funding process. However, in the funding stage the strength of the entrepreneur and the NVT becomes more important than the opportunity for investors investing in the new venture. Our results also indicate that lack of expertise makes angels more likely to increase the importance of one investment criteria over the other; however, the criteria emphasized differ depending on the type of expertise under consideration.

Title: Revisiting the link between leaders' emotional intelligence and transformational leadership: The moderating role of emotional intensity
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In a study of 192 managers using multiple methods and multiple raters, we examined whether the relationship between leaders¡̄ emotional intelligence and transformational leadership might differ across the levels of emotion intensity that they experienced at work. Consistent with our hypothesis, a positive relationship between leaders¡̄ emotional intelligence and their transformational leadership behaviors was observed for leaders with low, not high, emotional intensity; as such, leaders¡̄ emotional intensity indeed weakened the emotional intelligence-transformational leadership relationship. Theoretical and practical implications of this finding are discussed, with emphasis given to the importance of revisiting when emotional intelligence will aid versus potentially hurt leaders¡̄ transformational leadership behaviors.

Title: Transactive memory systems and group performance: A simulation study of the role of shared cognition
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: A transactive memory system (TMS), as the division of cognitive labor, is expected to contribute to group performance through effective information processing based on a shared mental model among group members. We focused on consensus as a key dimension of TMS, its relation to the volume of communication, group size, and presence of a social network, and its effect on performance. Through a computer simulation model, we found that the degree of consensus is positively related to the volume of communication, existence of a social network, and group performance, while group size is negatively related to the degree of consensus. The findings suggest the importance of facilitating the development of social networks in organizations and keeping group size relatively small.
