Title: A dynamic theory of technology commercialization strategy
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: A critical strategic decision facing a start-up firm with a technological innovation is how to access the financial resources and commercialization capabilities necessary to bring a product to market. The prior literature on commercialization strategy (Teece, 1986; Gans & Stern, 2003a) has focused on a one-off choice between contracting with an established firm to perform the commercialization activities and integrating downstream into the supply chain and commercializes its technology itself. It predicts that when the start-up firm has strong appropriability over its innovation but the established firms have tight control over the complementary assets the optimal arrangement is for the start-up firm to enter into a contracting (or licensing) arrangement with an established firm, relying on the latter to perform the commercialization tasks. However, while these conditions clearly prevail in the biopharmaceutical industry (Cohen, Nelson, & Walsh, 2000) and alliance arrangements are the predominant arrangement for commercializing this technology (Pisano, Shan, & Teece, 1988), the empirical evidence reveals that start-up biotech firms frequently increasingly seek to participate in the commercialization of the alliance product (known as co-development or co-promotion) and integrate downstream into marketing and distribution. In order to explain this pattern of arrangements, this paper develops a dynamic theory of technology commercialization strategy which introduces elements of organizational learning into the original theory of technology commercialization strategy. It argues that the start-up technology firms use their leverage in alliances with established product firms to acquire the specific knowledge about the downstream activities needed to build their own complementary assets. This in turn enables them to weaken the established firms' tight control over those assets and thereby appropriate more value from future innovations. It uses the theory to derive predictions for when a biotech firm is more likely to choose a hybrid arrangement, and tests these predictions on a dataset of 565 alliances between biotech and pharmaceutical firms from 1992-2006. The paper has implications not only for technology commercialization strategy, but also for our understanding of alliance arrangements and for industry dynamics.

Title: Chunky vs. Incremental growth: How to expand a search domain
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: As the number of interdependent decisions under a firm's purview grows, how should a firm structure this growth in order to reach high performance? For instance, should a component maker transform itself into a supplier of complex systems by slowly adding components one-by-one or by tackling the entire system in an integrated approach from the very beginning? This is but one instance of a general class of problems in design and strategy, in which decision makers need to find good solutions to a growing, complex set of decisions. To shed light on this problem, we use an agent-based simulation model to probe into the effects of growing a search domain in different ways. Our results make a case for growth by incremental steps: when dealing with a highly interdependent system, expanding a search domain step by step rather than in large chunks, or attempting to optimize an integrated system in its entirety, yields a distinct advantage in system performance. Furthermore, we find that it is more advisable to initially add larger chunks and then make small additions to a system, rather than starting small and adding larger chunks later. However, reaping the performance advantage of incremental expansion requires more time than an integrated approach. Allocating the available time intelligently across expansion stages can help smoothen this trade-off. For very short time frames, however, an integrated search can be optimal.

Title: Value creation in university-firm research collaborations: A matching approach
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: University research-based technological opportunities are often created and exploited through joint corporate and academic entrepreneurship activities such as university-industry research collaborations. What determines a "good match" between academic scientists and firms that seek to apply basic research for commercialization? To answer the question, this paper models firm-scientist alliance formation as an endogenous matching process driven by the synergy in knowledge-creation capabilities of the partners. The model is then applied to empirically investigate whether and when attributes such as knowledge breadth and depth, scientific and technological capabilities are complements or substitutes in knowledge creation. This study contributes to the management literature by introducing a model of alliance formation that explicitly addresses the endogeneity problem created by the self-selection of the partners into alliances. It also identifies the set of complementary capabilities required for a successful cross-organizational research relationship.

Title: No place like home? Spin-offs' strategy and location choice
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Previous studies suggest that spin-offs will locate in close proximity to the firm from which they spawned. As a result of this process, clusters of entrepreneurial activity tend to develop around a few strong parent firms. But do all spin-offs really stay close to home? In this article, we investigate which firms choose to stay nearby and which tend to leave. We test the predictive power of existing theories of location choice, and we develop a new theory particular to spin-off firms. We demonstrate that spin-off firms choose heterogeneous technological and market strategies, and we hypothesize that firms with more aggressive strategies have a greater need to maintain relationships that allow access to knowledge and facilitate coordination with complementors. We find supporting evidences of our arguments by analyzing the location and strategy decisions of intra-industry spin-offs in the disk drive industry.

Title: Owners on both sides of the deal: Mergers and acquisitions and overlapping institutional ownership
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Although management scholars debate the value creating potential of mergers and acquisitions, the practice is so widespread that the U.S. deals announced in the last decade exceed ten trillion dollars. The present study, using a corporate governance lens, examines the impact of heterogeneous interests of owners on mergers and acquisitions outcomes. In particular we look at how overlapping ownership, i.e. when owners have a stake in both the acquiring and the target firms, impacts the M&A gains of the acquirer. The empirical results suggest that when more institutional owners of the acquiring firm simultaneously hold stock in the target company, acquiring firms are more likely to destroy shareholder value through M&A deals; this effect however is constrained by stronger board control.

Title: A relational model of high performance work systems
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper we explore a causal mechanism through which high performance work systems influence performance outcomes. We propose a model in which a particular type of high performance work system - a relational work system - enhances organizational performance by creating a framework that encourages the development of social capital between employees who perform distinct functions. In a nine-hospital study of patient care, we show that the adoption of a relational work system predicts high levels of social capital among doctors, nurses, physical therapists, social workers and case managers in the form of relational coordination, in turn predicting quality and efficiency outcomes for patients. Results suggest that this social capital model of high performance work systems is a promising counterpart to models that focus on employee skills or commitment, and further suggest the potential for relational work systems to recognize and support the interdependent nature of work.

Title: What firms make vs. what they know: How firm boundaries affect competitive advantage
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Product innovations are often enabled by changes in components. We examine how firms' ability to manage such changes depends on their governance strategies, their knowledge of components, and the nature of technological change. Using data on all firms in the DRAM industry across 12 technology transitions from 1974 to 2005, we find that vertically integrating into component production improves firms' ability to manage technology transitions. Although non-integrated firms have lower performance, this effect is muted by the firms' component knowledge. Moreover, the relative advantage of extending production vs. knowledge boundaries is determined by two factors. The first is the nature of technological change - integrated firms have a greater advantage over non-integrated firms when innovation is architectural than when it is incremental. The second is the degree of integration - non-integrated firms derive greater benefit from their knowledge of external components than do integrated firms. Our results clarify the conditions under which extending knowledge boundaries can be a substitute for extending production boundaries in managing technological change.

Title: How do firm linkages with government reduce intensity of government corruption?
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study explores the relationship between network linkages and the intensity of government corruption. Based on resource dependence theory and institutional theory, we argue that linkages with government could enhance firm¡s legitimacy and reduce the environment uncertainty, thereby avoiding potential government corruption problems. We specify three types of linkages with government (governments as founders, shareholders, and clients) to test our theory. The empirical findings from a database of 1,034 firms in 23 emerging countries indicate that firms founded by governments and serving governments will have less government corruption problems.

Title: Creating value by giving it away: The influence of reciprocation on firm performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The assumption that economic actors behave in a boundedly self interested manner promises fruitful new insights for strategic management. A growing literature spanning multiple disciplines indicates most actors' selfish utility maximizing behaviors are bounded by norms of fairness. Rather than being purely self interested, people behave reciprocally by rewarding others' actions they deem fair and willingly incurring costs to punish those they deem unfair. Economists show that employers who are perceived distributionally fair by their employees generate comparatively more value due to the positively reciprocal behavior of those employees. The organizational justice literature distinguishes two additional types of fairness assessed by employees. Drawing from both of these bodies of work, we employ stakeholder theory to propose how perceptions of fairness result in reciprocity (1) extending to all stakeholders of the firm and (2) affecting value creation at the firm level.

Title: Cybersexual harassment: Development and validation of a measure of the online environment and online sexual harassment
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The use of online technology and computer-mediated communication continues to increase dramatically in organizations, bringing with it new avenues for sexual harassment. Despite the recognition that cybersexual harassment is an important phenomenon and that the online behaviors of employees can adversely affect the organization, there is little research on the development of instruments to measure related constructs. The present study is meant to be the first step in clearly defining and measuring the constructs relevant to online behavior at work. Scales are created to measure both perceptions of the online environment that are thought to precipitate the occurrence of harassment and intentions to engage in sexually harassing behavior using the Internet, an Intranet, or other computer technology. It is found that perceptions of the online environment as masculine and risk encouraging, where blatant prejudice is thought to be acceptable, are related to multiple forms of cybersexual harassment.

Title: Applying four-phase organizational learning theory to the Gospel of Luke: And interdisciplinary study
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper presents an exploratory interdisciplinary study that examines the Gospel of Luke through the lens of a four-phase organizational learning process. Our findings suggest that a four-phase social learning process is evident in the literary structure of Luke's chiastic Journey Narrative (Luke 9:51-19:28), as well as in some keystone passages like the Beatitudes and the Lord's Prayer. Implications for organizational theory are discussed.

Title: An integrative solution to the conflict over conflict
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Debate continues over the value of organizational conflict. Researchers from one tradition emphasize its constructive role in improving performance. Those from a second dispute this and emphasize its destructive effects on outcomes like satisfaction. I argue that this divergence primarily reflects narrow theoretical conceptions of conflict by each that are easily reconciled. An integrative model is proposed which describes the transformation of conflict over time and source using Pondy's (1967) stage model and the task versus relationship conflict distinction (Jehn, 1995). Latent task conflicts are those substantive differences among team members that generate superior collective outcomes. These are imperfectly perceived by members, which in turn may generate perceptions of relationship conflict. Perceived conflicts have little effect on performance but important consequences for satisfaction. Initial empirical support for the model was strong. In a natural experiment, teams with genuine task conflicts outperformed those without. However, there was little correlation between actual and perceived conflicts, and by extension little correlation between perceived conflicts and performance. Perceived task conflicts were positively associated with perceived relationship conflicts. Controlling for the latter, perceived task conflicts were unrelated to team satisfaction and actually increased individual satisfaction. The results underscore the importance of multiple levels of analysis. Most important, they replicate and integrate the empirical findings of two diverse research traditions under a unified conceptual model.

Title: Category spanning, naming strategies and performance implications in the US film industry
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper, we introduce naming as a legitimatizing tool that allows producers to use genre spanning as a way of differentiation without being ignored or devalued by audiences. With the product name providing a legitimacy shield, genre spanning helps reduce audience satiation and leads to higher performance of the product. In addition to the legitimacy shield function, the product name can also be manipulated to a certain extent and different naming strategies can be used to achieve distinctiveness. An analysis of film sequels released in the US market between 1982 and 2007 largely corroborated these propositions. The findings also indicate that the differentiation through genre spanning and naming strategies is more beneficial for the focal film sequel when the previous film in the same film series performs worse.

Title: Supply Chain governance in a creative industry: Offshore sourcing of special and visual effects
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This study addresses the issue of offshore sourcing of services in creative project based production. The authors develop hypotheses based in transaction cost economics that relate buyer and supplier experience, project type and the coordination requirements associated with different types of motion picture effects to the likelihood that a buyer will purchase services from an offshore supplier. Using archival data from the motion picture effects industry, the study finds that overall experience, which reduces buyer uncertainty, appear to play a greater role in offshore supply relationships than shared experience between buyer and supplier. Major projects intended for global audiences are more likely to go offshore. Visual effects, which require close coordination with the rest of the project are less likely to be sourced from offshore than special effects, despite the fact that visual effects are more highly modular and more likely to be produced digitally.

Title: Conceptualizing corporate social responsibility: An Indian perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Despite the proliferation of CSR related research in management literature, the numerous nuances of this multidisciplinary concept continue to pose challenges for a clear conceptualization. Moreover, the majority of academic CSR research focuses on evidences from developed countries, largely overlooking the cues from developing economies. Therefore, the addition of CSR viewpoints from an emerging economy can contribute invaluable insights to the growing body of scholarly work in this realm. This paper addresses this research gap by exploring CSR from an Indian perspective. Based on the Indian pharmaceutical industry, four case studies are complemented with 40 supplementary interviews with top management personnel within the industry. The results clearly suggest that the Indian perspective and practice of CSR differ significantly from the West. Three essential elements of the Western conceptualization of CSR - stakeholder pressure, environmental concerns and integration into core business are absent in India. Instead, the Indian CSR perceptions and practices seem to stem from the Gandhi's social trusteeship ideology, which perceives businesses as social development agents. The companies primarily focus their CSR activities on their employees, followed by the employees' families and the community. This finding adds to the debate of CSR conceptualization by highlighting the influence of the local context. This paper argues that the cultural heritage of corporate philanthropy and the current economic needs of social advancement shape the CSR practices in India. It thus calls for sensitivity to CSR's contextual idiosyncrasies, and opines against undifferentiated application of Western CSR concepts that ignore the local cultural context.

Title: The endogeneity of public policy in the dynamics of organizational populations
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In recent years, scholars working from the nascent institutional ecology perspective have demonstrated the powerful effects of public policy on the dynamics of organizational populations and have begun to explore the mechanisms through which these effects occur. However, interpretation of this work is clouded by a long-standing critique of the institutional ecology approach - that its results are potentially biased by the failure to account for the endogeneity of public policy formation. This paper examines the implications of this critique for institutional ecology by explicitly modeling the potential endogeneity of state life insurance policy in the dynamics of the early American life insurance population. It finds strong evidence of endogeneity and demonstrates that the true effects of public policy on organizational populations are only evident when such endogeneity is accounted for. It also explores the implications of these findings for institutional ecology and the study of institutional evolution.

Title: Unfolding the relationship between religion and socially responsible business conduct
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Existing empirical research offers conflicting outcomes with respect to the relationship between religion and socially responsible business conduct (SRBC). In this study, we examined the relationship between religion and SRBC by differentiating religion in terms of cognition, motivation, and behavior, and SRBC in terms of various behavioral aspects. Based on empirical research among 473 Dutch executives, we found that differentiating religion did not provide much additional insight into the relation between religion and SRBC, because the various dimensions of religion appear to be highly correlated. Measuring SRBC as a differentiated concept, however, importantly clarified the relationship between religion and SRBC, by showing significant but opposing influences of religion on various types of SRBC. In particular, traditional religious executives contributed more to SRBC in terms of charity but less to SRBC with respect to the internal stakeholders, providing equal opportunities to minorities and women, and the ecological environment.

Title: The autonomy trap: A cognitive perspective on the negative effects of individual autonomy
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: We suggest that granting decision-making autonomy to individuals can have negative effects on task performance. Two different negative effects are hypothesized and tested; a direct negative effect, caused by cognitive distraction (from the dual-task processing loss of task performance and decision-making), and an indirect effect (from individuals prematurely or incorrectly switching implementation methods). Results from two laboratory studies demonstrate both negative effects. The first study provides support for the notion of cognitive distraction as a mechanism (by biometrically measuring skin conductivity, as a proxy for attention and cognitive activity), and the second study supports the indirect negative effect.

Title: Strategic renewal in family firms: Role of successor's work experience and entrepreneurial self-efficacy
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper examines the important issue of strategic renewal in family firms by investigating the new business development abilities of family business successors. We do this by exploring the family business successor's self-efficacy, work experience (both within the family business and external to it) and the pursuit of novel initiatives. We find that experience in the family business gives the successors of the family businesses the cognitive abilities of entrepreneurial self efficacy, while external experience allows the successor to bring in new ideas and information which may lead to exploitation of new opportunities.

Title: How do VC firms evaluate startups' patent portfolios? The case of nanotechnology
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper analyzes how VC firms evaluate the patent portfolios of startup companies in their financing decisions. On one hand, we determine whether the amount of VCs' financing is associated with the size, technological focus and scope of patent portfolios of startup companies. On the other hand, we examine whether the valuation of patents varies across different types of VC firms, depending on their degree of industry specialization and affiliation. We provide empirical evidence from a sample of 332 VC-backed companies in the nanotechnology sector.

Title: Institutional and resource-based determinants of substantive implementation of ISO 14001
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Drawing on institutional theory and the resource-based view we examine antecedents of the inter-firm variance in the implementation of a management practice. Using survey data from 192 ISO 14001 certified facilities we find that motivations for adoption - seeking efficiency versus legitimacy - and complementary implementation and auditing capabilities affect implementation quality. We discuss implications for firm self-regulation through certifiable standards and suggest that combining institutional and resource-based theory improves our understanding of inter-firm variances in implementation of adopted practices.

Title: Capability transformation: Interplay between interest-alignment and knowledge-leveraging mechanisms
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In the resource-base view, the emphasis has been placed on the firm's ability to change and quickly develop new organizational capabilities as a critical prerequisite for sustainable competitive advantage. Calls have been made to study how firms change their capabilities, the issue that received less theoretical and empirical attention. The question we explore in this study is how do firms transform their capabilities through knowledge-intensive acquisitions? We focus on a specific capability as unit of analysis and employ the approach of theory building from multiple cases. We find that capability transformation involves a continuous iteration of knowledge leveraging and interest alignment mechanisms converging around a set of practices critical to capability, which we conceptualize as boundary practices. We generate propositions that suggest that knowledge leveraging and interest alignment mechanisms have a multiplicative joint effect on capability transformation mediated by the level of agreement about the boundary set of practices. The present study has implications to the literature on dynamic capabilities and to the broader literature on competitive advantage and resource-based view. By conceptualizing knowledge leveraging and interest alignment mechanisms and specifying their role in capability transformation, we contribute to developing a better link between the potential advantage derived from the availability of knowledge and how it translates into actual performance. Therefore the study starts to address recent calls to include organizational interest alignment dimension into the theory of competitive advantage.

Title: Paying right or paying high: The role of compensation policy and employee participation in improving SMEs' entrepreneurial action
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In the context of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), we reveal the importance of compensation policy in motivating employees to participate in their firm's pursuit of entrepreneurial strategies. Based on the experience of 1,745 Canadian SMEs, we found variable compensation improves employee participation, which in turn enhances SMEs' entrepreneurial action. This mediation effect is stronger for SMEs with low absolute compensation levels than SMEs with high absolute compensation levels. Such findings demonstrate a mechanism through which human resource management (HRM) helps realize entrepreneurial strategies through intervening employee behaviors.

Title: A study of race/ethnicity as a moderator of the relationship between social capital and satisfaction
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Research shows that occupation of key structural positions in social networks (structural social capital) is associated with positive outcomes. We integrate structural social network research with research in organizational/social psychology to propose that race/ethnicity may be a boundary condition to the positive relationship between structural social capital and positive outcomes. We carry out a social network study to test the effects of race/ethnicity as a moderator of the positive relationship between network centrality and satisfaction by collecting social network data (at two points in time) from an incoming cohort of business students. Our findings using the multiple regression quadratic assignment procedure (QAP) reveal that the relationship between network centrality and satisfaction is positive for Whites but not for minorities. Further, our analysis reveals that disadvantages for minorities persist over time. The theoretical and practical implications of our research are discussed.

Title: Adjusting virtual work practices: A qualitative study in knowledge intensive offshoring
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this qualitative exploratory research we contrast two globally distributed teams in organizations offshoring knowledge intensive work. Our evidence shows that, while both teams are deemed effective by their respective management, the individual adjustment to virtual work was smooth in one case and cumbersome in the other. We built a grounded theory that shows what the factors are that facilitate the acceptance of virtual work among knowledge professionals engaged in offshoring activities: integration with regular workflow, perception of offshoring activities, and perception of differences in competences and professional identity. We conclude with a discussion of theoretical and practical implications.

Title: Examining the situational and individual correlates of workplace connectivity behavior
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The advent of wireless email technology available through laptops and handheld devices is rapidly turning what has traditionally been a fixed form of communication into a portable one. As a result, workplace communication is becoming fully mobile and essentially fully synchronous, enabling organization employees to remain connected to the workplace from any location, at any time. Prior researchers have examined the antecedents of technology adoption and use, but little empirical research has been done on the use of wireless email and telephony devices. We therefore conducted an organizational survey to investigate the situational and individual correlates of workplace connectivity behavior (CB). Data from 141 full-time working adults revealed that CB was significantly related to the distribution of a wireless email device by one's organization, organizational norms, and individual difference variables related to orientations around time and work, including polychronicity and role integration preference.

Title: Contributions of work-life and resilience initiatives to the Individual/Organization relationship
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The processes by which work-life initiatives enhance employee commitment, satisfaction and well-being, and the conditions required for this to happen, remain a black box. In an effort to crack the black box open, this article investigates the outcomes of work-life, well-being and resilience initiatives on the Individual/Organization relationship. The research is based on a qualitative and inductive analysis of 73 semi-structured interviews with US and UK employees, in a multinational pharmaceutical company. This article offers a typology of the seven distinct outcomes of the initiatives that have been identified, as well as a decision tree to understand the processes by which the same set of initiatives impacts employees so differently. While the outcomes are positive for almost two thirds of the sample (loyalty, pride, calculated appreciation and use as management tools), some are negative (disappointment/resentment, obligation to stay), and one is neutral (indifference). The key factors explaining this broad range of outcomes are (a) awareness of the initiatives, (b) degree of need for them, (c) access to them, and (d) the employee's judgment of the employer. Although these findings are partially explained by theoretical frameworks currently applied in the work-life field, such as perceived organizational support, others clearly call for new theoretical foundations.

Title: Coping with the constraints of self-employment: A person-situation model of entrepreneurial burnout
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Burnout is a serious concern among entrepreneurs, particularly self-employed entrepreneurs, who work long hours and face many constraints with minimal social support. Situational factors have been the primary focus of burnout researchers, but personal factors impact perception of and reaction to situational factors. Accordingly, we advocate an interactionist model to provide a more comprehensive explanation of burnout among entrepreneurs. We hypothesized that conscientiousness compensates for neuroticism to enable self-employed entrepreneurs cope more effectively with constraints, thereby minimizing burnout. As expected, we found a significant three-way interaction among our three predictors. The strongest positive relationship between neuroticism and burnout was among low-conscientious entrepreneurs facing many constraints. We propose that coping is the central explanation behind this finding. Specifically, in the absence of conscientiousness, neurotic entrepreneurs cope less effectively with constraints and subsequently experience more burnout. However, if they also have conscientious characteristics, which are associated with productive coping styles, entrepreneurs can deal more effectively with constraints and more successfully avoid burnout. Past research suggests a strong relationship between personality and coping, particularly in high stress situations (Connor-Smith & Flachsbart, 2007). We extend these findings and suggest that personality interacts with the situation by determining coping strategies and subsequent burnout. Personality and situational factors should perhaps both be considered in burnout research and burnout-reduction interventions, particularly for self-employed entrepreneurs.

Title: The influence of peer cheating behavior on observers' cheating behavior: A social cognitive perspective
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The relationship between peer cheating behavior and observers' cheating behavior has generally been examined from a social learning perspective. We employ two additional theoretical lenses, social identity theory and social comparison theory, each of which offers additional insight into this relationship. These theories form the conceptual foundation for this study and are used to shed light on the relationship between peer cheating behavior and observers' cheating behavior in U.S. business schools. Data from 600 undergraduate business students in two universities provide general support for all three theoretical models. Implications for business schools, faculty, and future research are discussed.

Title: Which firms invest for the long term? Longitudinal evidence from cable TV operators
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Managers often favor investments with short payoff horizons over alternatives with better but deferred returns. Beyond the traditional explanation of agency conflict, this paper establishes that firms' capital availability influences investment patterns. Evidence from a 543-observation data panel for cable TV operators from 1972-1996 - where payoff horizon is analyzed in a multi-stage system of equations - confirms that long horizon investments are more likely in firms with high capital availability, and such firms are also better positioned to benefit from them. Additionally, results show that stock options only promote long horizon investment during the relatively short period when they are unexercisable.

Title: Golden helix or tangled web? How gene patent landscape impacts knowledge use and follow-on innovation
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Once taken-for-granted as the engine driving commercialization of science, patents are now controversial. As the intellectual property landscape has become more complex and characterized by patent thickets and ownership fragmentation and as patents are increasingly uncertain in scope and strength, scholars have argued over the detrimental impacts on follow-on innovation. Another argument highlights the positive effects of patenting on public research. These debates collide when we consider patents on human genes. Little evidence exists to adjudicate the pros and cons of gene patents even as U.S. Congressional Bills propose their ban. Using a sample of matched gene patents and papers we find that patenting impedes follow-on use of gene papers by 5-17%. The effect increases in the patent scope, thicket and with ownership fragmentation and disease association. Our findings inform policy and speak to the growing importance of strategic management of science as a focus for managerial scholarship.

Title: The governance paradox: Balancing autonomy and control in managing communities of practice
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In management theory and practice, communities of practice have become increasingly influential as social structures in which knowledge can be created and shared. Initially presented as spontaneous and self-organizing processes, recent studies describe communities as amenable to manipulation and suggest a governance approach that balances autonomy and control. This paper presents a process model of governance in communities of practice, focusing on the question of how organizations combine different governance mechanisms for a balanced management of these emergent structures. Drawing on data from an inductive study of 16 communities in nine organizations, we reveal three governance patterns, each associated with different learning processes and representing a different path towards a balance between autonomy and control: (1) expanding communities focused on recombining bodies of knowledge supported by a governance pattern that achieves balance within multiple governance mechanisms; (2) leveraging communities dedicated to knowledge replication supported by a governance pattern that combines strong technical authority with low disciplinary authority; and (3) probing communities focused on exploring new knowledge supported by a governance pattern that replaces direct control with indirect nurturing of the community's routines. This paper contributes to organizational control theory by revealing the different governance patterns deployed to balance autonomy and control in communities of practice. It also contributes to organization learning and design theories by revealing different learning processes and the related organizational features that constitute the three types of communities of practice.

Title: Drivers of organizational social capital in the Firm. An empirical exploration
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper we investigated the impact of organizational context and supportive managerial behaviour on the creation of the internal social capital at a business-unit level. Organizational context, defined as the set of administrative and social mechanisms of influence implemented by management to shape the behaviour and attitudes of employees, arises as a key organizational attribute to facilitate the creation of internal social capital in the firm. Further, internal social capital impact on firm's financial performance is confirmed. Data collected from 1,817 individuals in 36 international business units supported our hypotheses.

Title: Enhancing nurse job satisfaction: The importance of a servant leader orientation in health care management
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Ensuring a quality nursing workforce for the future in a time of increasing labor shortage and declining nurse satisfaction is a key challenge to the health care industry. Understanding what impacts job satisfaction is vital to solving the problem of nurse attrition (Fletcher, 2001). While many studies have examined nurse satisfaction at the individual level of analysis, this study empirically tests the impact of nurse managers' servant leadership orientation on nurse job satisfaction. Nursing is a unique occupation in that it requires both competence in professional service as well as compassion in patient caregiving. While many service occupations exist, nursing is one of the few to have such a high expectation of personal and relational care for the one that is served. We suggest that this element of care requires additional expectations of managers who supervise in-patient nursing staff. Statistical findings of this study provide evidence that behaviors and attitudes of the nurse manager do impact job satisfaction both individually and within the work group as a whole. Departments where managers had higher servant leadership orientation not only demonstrated significant positive impact on individual employee job satisfaction, but the managerial orientation also impacted group job satisfaction. In addition, there is some indication that this servant leader orientation might ultimately be an important predictor of higher unit productivity based on organizational measures such as personnel turnover and patient care.

Title: Representational gaps, team Integration and team creativity
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Functional diversity is central to the performance of product development teams in that multiple perspectives increase the team's creativity. Failures in cross-functional product development teams (CFPDTs) are often attributed to a team's inability to capitalize on their diversity. In this study we develop and test a model based on the representational gaps perspective (Cronin & Weingart, 2007; Weingart, Cronin, Houser, Cagan, & Vogel, 2005) to determine factors that promote or limit creativity in CFPDTs. In particular we examine how representational gaps and cognitive and affective integration in CFPDTs affect coordination and conflict, which in turn influence the novelty and usefulness of the products designed. Furthermore, we investigate when conflict resulting from the representational gaps stimulates or harms creativity. We test these relationships using a path analysis on data across two time periods from cross-functional product development student teams. Representational gaps, affective integration, and cognitive integration were found to collectively improve team creativity via task conflict, relationship conflict, and coordination. Representational gaps and cognitive integration largely influenced creativity through task conflict, coordination, and conflict management. Affective integration operated via its effect on relationship conflict and an interactive effect with cognitive integration on task conflict. Furthermore, the effects of conflict and coordination on creativity depended on the conflict management approach used by the group. We discuss these findings in detail and end by considering the implications for the management of cross functional teams engaged in potentially creative work.

Title: Knowledge that flows and knowledge that grows: Inventive performance in the semiconductor field
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper aims to extend our understanding of the inventive process in the context of organizational fields. To this end, the paper integrates two well-established yet largely unrelated notions about the inventive process. On the one hand, research has shown that knowledge circulates unevenly among the firms populating a field, forming an inter-organizational network of knowledge flows. On the other hand, firms continuously renew and transform the knowledge that flows through this network as a consequence of their knowledge absorption and knowledge generation activities. Bringing these views together allows us to present a more encompassing picture of the inventive process, and it yields a set of novel testable hypotheses. Based on a sample of companies operating in the semiconductor industry over the period 1976-2002, our hypotheses are corroborated.

Title: The psychological contract: Investigation of generational and career stage differences
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Psychological contract theorists have posited that individual differences in employees' work attitudes and behaviours influence how the psychological contract is perceived. However, research investigating the psychological contract has largely failed to consider potential individual differences. This study expands current research through investigating whether employees perceptions of employer obligations and cognitive reactions to fulfilment of these obligations vary based on an individual's career stage and generational cohort. Over 250 employees with backgrounds across diverse industry sectors and positions participated in the study. Results indicate that across employees, level of perceived balanced obligations were significantly higher than perceived level of relational or transactional obligations. This study found significant differences between individuals' perceptions of the psychological contract based on their generational cohort and career stage. The implications of these results to theory, future research and practice are discussed.

Title: Dormant ties: The value of reconnecting
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The prevailing view of social network ties is that, if not continually maintained, they will wither and disappear, losing their value as social capital. In contrast, we propose that dormant ties-i.e., former ties in which two parties have lost touch-can be a valuable source of knowledge if re-connected. Moreover, we predict that dormant ties that were once strong ties can combine the two benefits of weak ties (efficiency and novelty) with the two benefits of strong ties (solidarity and comprehension). Our research observes the effects of executives who consulted with their dormant ties about an important work project. The results indicate that executives spent considerably less time consulting with their reconnected dormant ties than with their current ties, yet rated usefulness as either comparable or better. Also, as predicted, dormant strong ties combined all four benefits of network ties. These results point to the value of dormant ties as an overlooked and largely untapped source of social capital.

Title: Institutional entrepreneurship and the emergence of hedge funds: The rich historical case
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: While thought of as a hyper-rational free-market solution to wealth management, the field of hedge funds is rooted in a highly institutionalized environment; its very development depended on significant institutional innovation by knowledgeable actors acting as institutional entrepreneurs long before the first organizational form appeared. The relevant institutions continue to constrain and enable the field's organizational entrepreneurs today. Nonetheless, there are no studies in the economic sociology and organizational theory literatures regarding this important industry. This qualitative study seeks to shed light on issues of emergence: how fields of economic activity emerge, who are the relevant institutional and organizational entrepreneurs in such a process, and the consequences of shifting social environments to the organizational entrepreneurs seeking to establish firms in an emerging industry.

Title: CSR in conflict prone areas: An empirical investigation in Lebanon
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: We have witnessed in recent years the ascendancy of a heated debate about the link between business activities and conflict around the world. This debate, which is increasingly being framed in the context of a broadened CSR agenda, focuses on one hand on instances of complicity of corporations in violence and human rights abuses, and on the other hand on identifying ways to strengthen private sector involvement and investment in responsible business management, conflict prevention, peace building, and post-conflict reconstruction. This paper aims at shedding light on the multidimensional role that MNCs can play in conflict prone areas in light of the changing context of business through a review of the existing literature about conflict and the linkages between business and conflict. An empirical investigation of business-conflict linkages in a developing country context is then presented. The paper capitalizes on in-depth interviews with a sample of MNCs operating in Lebanon to gauge their perceptions of business-conflict relationships, and actual measures and actions adopted before, during and after conflict situations. The findings are fleshed out and relevant implications drawn regarding the role of MNCs in conflict zones in the context of a broadened CSR agenda.

Title: On a short leash? Young organizations, strategic change, and venture capital
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: A vast literature chronicles the struggles of established firms to adapt given environmental change, but few studies have examined whether young organizations are indeed more adaptive than their senior corporate siblings. Firms attempting to commercialize inventions during a period of rapid technological change may need to adapt their strategies as they learn, but established organizations often remain tied to existing paths. Nascent firms less subject to inertia may be better poised to explore various commercialization avenues but are resource-constrained. While external investment may promise to solve the resource problem, might investors reduce a firm's adaptability? Using a data set chronicling technology commercialization strategies and funding events of all firms in the worldwide automatic speech recognition industry from 1952-2006, I investigate the impact of these factors on young firms and strategic change.

Title: The base-of-the-pyramid perspective: A new approach to poverty alleviation
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: While interest and debate about the base of the pyramid (BoP) as a poverty alleviation perspective is growing, most of the current research has focused on the business landscape and market entry strategies for organizations interested in serving these markets. Indeed, a deep exploration of the unique poverty alleviation implications of a BoP perspective has lagged. With a growing number of organizations from the development, non-profit, and private sectors claiming to incorporate BoP ventures as part of their portfolio of activities, this gap in our knowledge is increasingly untenable. The purpose of this paper is to review the existing literature on the BoP and put forth a set of principles that distinguish the BoP perspective from other poverty alleviation approaches. These principles also provide insight on when a BoP perspective is most effective and how it can complement other poverty reduction efforts.

Title: Travel incentives as tournament compensation - Problems of contestant heterogeneity and solutions
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Whereas the theoretical literature on organizational reward systems repeatedly points to the importance of tournament models from an efficiency perspective, very few is known about the application and effectiveness of tournament compensation in organizations, especially when contestant heterogeneity is taken into account. While the distorting effects of contestant heterogeneity on tournament incentives have been theoretically analyzed for the two-contestant-case, tournament incentives in a typical organizational context with more than two and with heterogeneous contestants and with more than one prize, have not been studied so far. In our paper, we analyze these effects theoretically as well as empirically by studying in-centive travel sales contests as a quantitatively important component of compensation, and we also present first empirical evidence on (successful and unsuccessful) organizational attempts to reduce contestant heterogeneity by active handicapping and league-building.

Title: Before identity: The emergence and objectification of new organizational forms
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The evolution of new organizational forms has attracted growing theoretical and empirical attention, but little research has considered the micro-social processes that promote the emergence of quasi-similar organizations that may evolve over time into organizational forms with distinctive identities that are both claimed and granted. Drawing on social psychological theories of identity formation within and among organizational groups, we develop a model of identification and identity development for organizational forms that underpins arguments from ecological and institutional theory.

Title: The effects of bundled knowledge stocks on innovative success
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: As firms engage in building different R&D capabilities, they confront a crucial question: What configuration of knowledge stocks is most likely to increase innovative success? We argue that the impact of one knowledge stock may depend not just on its level but also the level of other stocks and the interdependencies of firms' existing knowledge stocks might explain performance differences. We measure the effects of three pairwise combinations of knowledge stocks on firm innovative success and find, using an event history analysis of 857 dedicated biotechnology firms during 1973-1999, that two pairs are complementary (i.e., intellectual and human capital; collective and human capital) and one pair is substitutive (i.e., intellectual and collective capital). We therefore suggest a system theory of intra-organizational knowledge: The substitutability and complementarities of multiple knowledge sources moderate their direct relationship with innovative success.

Title: A multidimensional view of personal reputations
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Despite the importance of personal reputations in many workplaces, research has not established a full characterization of the construct. In particular, prior work has focused on the favorability of the employee's reputation (i.e., how positive or negative it is) and has paid little attention to other important dimensions, such as breadth (how widespread the reputation is), salience (how accessible the reputation is) and consensus (how well agreed upon the reputation is). In this paper, I argue for a multidimensional characterization of personal reputations that incorporates these dimensions. I describe how the dimensions vary across individuals, domains and stakeholder groups, and the importance of these dimensions for determining reputation effects.

Title: What time is it? Coordinating pacing mechanisms in drug discovery
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The literature on pacing and entrainment reveals little information on how event pacing and time pacing can be coordinated under circumstances of coexistence. However, we found this to be a central managerial problem for organizations in the biopharmaceutical industry which engage in the drug discovery process. Because of the nature of their work, scientists tend to pace based on events whereas managers pace the organization based on time. Challenges arise when work needs to be coordinated among these different complex knowledge systems at distinct points in time. We develop a grounded theory on how coordination of event and time pacing can be achieved through three mechanisms: resource augmentation, bundling and routinization, and selling forward.

Title: How risk mediates the CSP-CFP relationship
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: What is the relationship between corporate social performance (CSP) and corporate financial performance (CFP)? This empirical study uses bond market data to assess the relationship, arguing that if CSP is related to CFP it would be over the long-term, and that therefore long-term bonds are a more the suitable security to study rather than stocks. It is further proposed that CSP affects risk, and that it is risk that then affects the firm's financial performance. Thus risk is proposed to be an intermediary between CSP and CFP. Mediated regression is therefore used to assess the relationship between CSP (as measured by KLD) and CFP (as measured by the yield-to-maturity, YTM, on bonds). Risk is measured by the Moody's risk rating on a firm's long-term bonds, because it is a forward-looking measure and a long-term measure, and is therefore an appropriate measure of long-term future risk. Regression results show that the Moody's risk rating does fully mediate the relationship between KLD and YTM. Other backwards-looking risk measures-beta, the current ratio, and the standard deviation of EBIT-do not.

Title: Director capabilities, information processing demands and board effectiveness
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Boards of directors are integral to the modern corporation and therefore frequently studied. However, recent corporate scandals as well as mixed empirical findings about the impact of board structure highlight the fact that there is still much to learn. The purpose of this study is to incorporate the concept of board-level capabilities into research on corporate governance by proposing and developing the construct of director capabilities. Drawing upon a range of theoretical perspectives including human capital, information processing, and learning, we argue that, in order to understand board effectiveness, corporate governance research must go beyond its traditional focus on structural independence to also include directors' capabilities to monitor and participate in strategic decision making. Specifically, we argue that directors are able to contribute more effectively to the extent that they possess greater amounts of human capital, and that their ability to contribute is likely to be lowered by greater information processing demands posed by their home companies. We test our hypotheses using archival data on 650 firms randomly sampled from the Fortune 1000 over the years 2000 through 2003, which resulted in a unique data set on the human capital characteristics of more than 5700 corporate directors. By providing evidence in support of our hypotheses, this paper expands our understanding of the antecedents of board effectiveness.

Title: Narcissism in management education
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: A recent meta-analysis (Twenge, Konrath, Foster, Campbell, & Bushman, in press) found that narcissism levels in U.S. college students have steadily risen over the past 25 years, and there is some evidence that high levels of narcissism may be even more pronounced among business students in comparison with those in other disciplines (e.g., Robak, Chiffriller, and Zappone, 2007). This increase in narcissism has implications for both student classroom behavior and the manner in which we, as faculty, effectively teach and manage our classrooms. In the present paper, we discuss the personality trait of narcissism and its potential manifestations in the classroom. We then offer suggestions for management educators in dealing with more narcissistic students to overcome some of their counterproductive tendencies and increase their chances for success in the classroom.

Title: Front-line staff perspectives on opportunities for improving the safety and efficiency of hospital work systems
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper reports on a patient safety intervention conducted with 20 U.S. hospitals from 2004-2006. Senior managers observed frontline staff as they worked and facilitated open discussion meetings with employees about their patient safety-related concerns. The intervention activities generated a database of 1732 staff-identified safety concerns, which we analyzed for type of failure and frequency of occurrence. We also compared these staff-identified safety concerns with recommendations from national initiatives. The two most frequent categories of staff safety-concerns, equipment/supplies and facility issues, posed safety risks and diminished staff efficiency, but have not been priorities in national initiatives. Our study suggests an underutilized strategy for improving patient safety and efficiency: Leveraging front-line staff experiences with their work systems to identify opportunities for improvement. In contrast to the perceived tradeoff between safety and efficiency, fixing work systems can yield benefits for both. Thus, prioritizing improvement of work systems in general, rather than focusing more narrowly on specific clinical conditions, can increase safety and efficiency of hospitals.

Title: Rescuing latent technologies: A relational model of technology managers
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The transfer of technology from universities to firms is valuable because of the royalties universities earn support current and future scientific and technological advances (Powell & Owen-Smith, 1998; Mowery, 2004; Mowery, 2001). Universities across the nation face a dilemma of generating a return on investments from the transfer of latent technologies that have potential commercial value, but are unfamiliar and difficult to evaluate. Recent perspectives in the technology transfer literature have suggested that university inventions are channeled to firms through transactions in an efficient market for patent protected intellectual property (Agarwal, 2001). This paper argues that this transaction model can be effective for non-latent technologies but suggests that a relational model of technology transplantation more effectively accounts for the process through which university technology managers identify and transfer latent technologies. An organizational ethnography is used to identify how latent technologies are defined and how this subclass of technologies is transferred through a four-phase process involving the following practices: access, extraction, representation, and orchestration. Implications of this relational model of technology transplantation for research and practice of technology transfer are discussed.

Title: Organizing project-based learning in work contexts: A cross-cultural cross analysis of data
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: We describe research aimed at developing a more comprehensive framework for project-based learning in work contexts. This grows out of a cross-cultural re-analysis of data from two previous studies using two different frameworks: actor-centered learning-network theory and the "critical pragmatist" lens on action-reflection learning. Findings are based on a cross-analysis of a sub-set of one another's data sets using our respective original frameworks, thus intending to build reflexivity into the latter. We identify strengths and weaknesses of each framework and discuss a more comprehensive framework that takes into account both individual and organizational learning, at a time when learning in work contexts is increasingly driven by the learner and integrated with work.

Title: Exclusion, hazard, adding value, or learning? Diversity strategies focused on employees with a migration background
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper we develop a theoretically founded typology of diversity strategies through combining elements of strategy research, diversity research, and resource dependence theory. Thereby, we focus on the question why persons with a migration background are (not) employed. We argue that employment decisions are based on the evaluation of critical re-sources and the quest to secure their accrual. We classify resources related to the (non)employment of persons with a migration background and designate each diversity strat-egy by their importance. Furthermore, we derive propositions regarding the configuration of personnel structures and practices related to the diversity strategies and their relationship to context variables.

Title: Environmental regulation as a link between corporate environmental and financial performance
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Current work on the link between corporate environmental performance (CEP) and corporate financial performance (CFP) moves beyond searching for a global correlation between the two to identifying and testing the mechanisms through which CEP may impact CFP. The purpose of this paper is to examine one such mechanism: that strong CEP allows firms to gain competitive advantage by raising their rivals costs (more than their own) through lobbying for stricter environmental regulation. It examine this issue in the context of the global automobile industry between 1968 and 2000, hypothesizing that high-CEP automakers influenced the global spread of automobile emission standards and benefitted competitively from increases in the stringency of emission standards. Results confirm these hypotheses.

Title: Systemizing the organizational scenario literature using Morgan's metaphors
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: This paper provides an initial classification of the organizational scenario literature based on Morgan's (1986) influential treatment of the general organizational literature. The exploratory study is unique in that no classification of the scenario literature using Morgan's eight metaphors has previously been undertaken. The aim of the classification is to begin to order the scenario literature which is currently under-systematized. It is hoped that this ordering will enable consultants to better understand the many competing claims and facets of scenario work as well as when to emphasize certain aspects of the methodology (given the particular practical situation being addressed). The result of this initial classification is the ordering of 190 pieces of scenario literature themed within each of the metaphors as well as a discussion of key observations related to undertaking this classification. While this is an exploratory study, the intent is to further develop this classification for publication. It is hoped that just as Morgan's analysis opened up a whole new line of theorizing in the general organizational literature, this classification may start the same sort of development in the organizational scenario literature.

Title: Contested meaning: Power and frames in IT implementation
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Research on the organizational implementation of IT and social power has favored explanations based on issues of resource power and process power at the expense of matters of meaning power. As a result, although the existence and importance of meaning power is acknowledged, its distinct properties and especially its enactment patterns, practices and purposes remain relatively under-theorized and under-explored by IT researchers. This paper focuses on unpacking the practices and purposes associated with the exercise of meaning power within the IT implementation process. Our aim is to analyze the practices employed to manage meaning and enact consequential "definitions of the situation," as well as the purposes behind these deliberate meaning construction activities. We employ frame analysis and the signature matrix technique to analyze the enactment of meaning power in practice. The paper develops and illustrates this conceptual framework using a case study of IT implementation in a challenging public sector environment. We conclude by pointing out the situated nature of meaning power enactment and the associated outcomes. Our research extends the literature on IT and social power by offering an analytical framework distinctly suited to the analysis and deeper understanding of meaning power per se.

Title: The determinants of technology commercialization in British and German biotechnology
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The intention of this paper is to investigate whether companies' strategic decision making in "liberal market economies" is more strongly driven by market-related factors compared to companies in "coordinated economies". Thereby, we focus on a particularly important strategic decision firms face - the commercialization choice. Using a unique survey dataset on the commercialization of British and German biotechnology firms, we analyze the determinants of commercialization strategy, paying particular attention to national idiosyncrasies. Together, the findings indicate that the commercialization strategy follows distinct patterns in the British "liberal market economy" and the German "coordinated economy".

Title: Tie versus tie: When do corporate development activities strengthen or disrupt buyer-supplier ties?
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper, we explore the effect of a firm's corporate development activity history on its propensity to maintain long-term buyer-supplier relations. More precisely, we examine various forms of corporate development, i.e. alliance, equity joint ventures and acquisitions, and explore how experience with these activities differentially affects the likelihood of tie dissolution. We argue that corporate development activities will provide opportunities for learning resulting from experience spillovers, but also bring about considerable disruptions. Taking both these arguments into account, we postulate a U-shaped relationship between a firm's CDA experience and the likelihood of its ties ending in a given year. We find support for our proposed curvilinear relationship between CDA experience and likelihood of tie dissolution in a sample of 273 advertising agency-client ties. We also hypothesize and find empirically that the effects of different types of experience are not uniform. We examine differences between acquisitions, joint ventures and other alliances and between horizontal and vertical CDA effects. We thus show that not all types of experience provide the same learning opportunities and disruptive potential for buyer-supplier ties. Although learning spillovers occur, we find limits to the benefits of experience as well as evidence of learning asymmetries.

Title: Distributive negotiation as a gender trigger
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: As an extension of the construct of gender triggers recently introduced in the negotiation literature, this study tested whether the degree of association among aspiration level, intended opening offer, actual first offer, and final agreement was moderated by negotiator gender. Results show that gender does moderate the association between the predictor variables of aspiration level and intended opening offer and the criterion variable of actual first offer. The test of moderation for the association between actual first offer and final agreement was not significant. These results suggest that this gender trigger is associated with first offers, but may not be related to final agreements once those offers are made.

Title: Managerial ethics, performance pressure and governance: The case of misleading financial disclosures
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: While it is generally acknowledged that the majority of executives are honest, the continuing torrent of financial restatements, corporate scandals, executive malfeasance, and litigation provides a reality check. By addressing the impact that personal characteristics have on managerial willingness to lie about financial performance, this work adds a new dimension to the emerging stream of research exploring the drivers of misleading financial disclosures. Using a scenario-and-survey methodology with more than 100 managers enrolled in a MBA program, we found that ethical ideology and normative beliefs drive the intent to engage in misleading behavior and, when the intent is there, individuals are willing to follow through on the action. We also found that imposed pressure to perform further accentuates the effect of attitudes towards ethical behavior on the intention to mislead. Our findings indicated that board power has a significant effect on misleading intentions, albeit in a direction opposite to that hypothesized and, somewhat disturbingly, organizational ethical climate, firm size, and the type of firm ownership had no effect on individuals' willingness to mislead. Given those outcomes, this work has practical implications for the hiring and oversight of executives and middle-level managers.

Title: Examining the interaction of diversity and personality - The role of need for cognition
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In a study of 73 teams from eight organizations, we examined the average need for cognition as a moderator of the relationship of both age and educational diversity with the elaboration of task-relevant information, collective team identification, and team performance, respectively. Both types of diversity were positively related to these outcomes only when the average need for cognition was high rather than low. We found mixed support for mediated moderation effects. Our study advances knowledge of when and how diversity benefits team outcomes by underscoring the need to examine as moderators the personalities of those who interact in diverse teams.

Title: The ambidextrous organization in practice: Barriers to innovation within research and development
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper, we study the influence of different forms of ambidexterity on practical challenges to innovation in organizations. It is widely accepted that innovative companies have to pursue exploitative and explorative innovation activities at the same time, either in separated business units or integrated within a single business unit. However, research on the practical consequences of introducing and following the logics of ambidexterity in an organization is scarce. Following a case study-based approach, we develop a barriers approach to innovation based on an explorative study of 10 research and development projects in the automotive industry. By identifying specific barriers to an innovation project, it is possible to outline possible shortcomings of a given organizational structure. We are able to develop six main categories of barriers based on 152 descriptions of different barriers to innovation. Our findings show that projects in a separated research and development environment mainly experience problems in interdepartmental collaboration. Those projects in integrated research and development environments on the other hand, mostly suffer from a lack of motivation for explorative activities, while exploitative activities are preferred. Moreover, there seem to be fewer problems installing adequate structures for organizational ambidexterity compared to implementing these new structures in the mind of the innovators and top management. We discuss possible underlying reasons for these observations and suggest solutions based on research on different roles in innovation management.
