Title: Total disclosure versus keeping secrets: Managing causal ambiguity for competitive advantage
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Causal ambiguity describes a lack of knowledge or understanding of cause-and-effect interactions between firm resources and competitive advantage on the part of internal decision makers and/or rivals external to the firm. An inability to identify and understand the relationship between valuable resources and firm performance is consequential because it constrains a firm's ability to replicate valuable capabilities and thereby extend its advantage but at the same time, offers a means of protecting those capabilities from imitation by external agents. Prior research has not resolved this causal ambiguity paradox and most recommendations involve adapting to a capability's position along a causal ambiguity paradox. Rather than assuming causal ambiguity is a feature of a firm's resource structure that must be accommodated, the authors propose viewing causal ambiguity as an attribute that can be deliberately managed and adjusted to overcome the paradox and achieve competitive advantage by influencing key sources of ambiguity. Sources of ambiguity that arise from the resource structure, from a firm's knowledge management practices, and from decision maker characteristics are explored. Three approaches to managing causal ambiguity are examined: (1) Lowering causal ambiguity but preserving inimitability through other factors; (2) reducing causal ambiguity in ways that are contextually dependent within the focal firm and therefore only visible within firm boundaries; and (3) managing replication and transfer strategies without reducing causal ambiguity. This analysis reframes the causal ambiguity paradox and offers avenues for future research that have been overlooked by prior perspectives and a menu of options for managers to consider.
Index Keywords: Competition; Knowledge management; Causal ambiguity; Cause and effects; Competitive advantage; Firm Performance; Inimitability; Knowledge management practices; Resource-based view; Transfer strategies; Decision making

Title: Negotiating gender stereotypes: Other-advocacy reduces social constraints on women in negotiations
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The author proposes that distributive bargaining is considered masculine and incongruent with feminine gender stereotypes. For women, negotiating assertively to attain better salary outcomes carries the risk of grave social costs. Hence, women tend to negotiate less assertively, attaining lower salaries, in order to avoid social sanctions or backlash for violating feminine gender stereotypes. Given this account, I hypothesize that the effect of gender on negotiation outcomes should be moderated by advocacy - whether a woman negotiates on her own behalf or another's behalf. Specifically, women should do worse than men only when negotiating on their own behalf. Other-advocacy attenuates the likelihood of social backlash for assertive behavior by moderating the extent to which assertive negotiating is incongruent with feminine gender stereotypes. Data from three studies found that women agree to worse outcomes and behave less competitively when negotiating on their own behalf, and that their unassertiveness is mediated by anticipation of social backlash.

Title: Heterogeneity among survivors of a competence-destroying technological discontinuity
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to investigate alternate routes to surviving a competence-destroying technological discontinuity. While previous research on technological discontinuities has focused on differences between survivors and non-survivors, the focus here is on heterogeneity among survivors, specifically the ten survivors of the technological discontinuity in the 3D computer graphics chips industry in the mid 1990s. An inductive case study analysis of archival data indicates that the survivors cluster into two groups representing two very different enacted strategies: technological leaders and market niche players. By being able to shape the technological uncertainties associated with an era of ferment, technological leader became less vulnerable to demand uncertainties. In contrast, market niche firms selected, or were selected by, particular markets, and their more limited exposure to demand uncertainties rendered them less vulnerable to technological uncertainties.

Title: Examining experience and its role in dynamic versus static decision-making effectiveness among professionals
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: While a number of researchers have focused on the role of experience as a determinant of decision effectiveness among professionals, there is a paucity of research examining how the nature of this relationship may vary with regard to different types of decision tasks (i.e., static versus dynamic). Based on an inductive study of professional trial lawyers, the findings reported here demonstrate that dynamic decision-making effectiveness increases through experience, in part due to an increase in mindfulness. At the same time, static decision-making effectiveness may become compromised at high levels of experience due to several phenomena revealed in this study.

Title: Perfect storm: A cross-level study of transformational leadership during scandal-exacerbated decline
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Although there have been studies of employee reactions to change as well as organizational decline, there have not been studies of employee reactions to management actions during scandal-exacerbated decline. We hypothesize that membership in a business unit experiencing scandal would have group level effects on the individual, while transformational leadership actions would have direct effects at the individual level. In analyzing more than 2800 employee survey responses, we used Hierarchical Linear Modeling to examine the effects of scandal at the group level as well as at the individual level. We extend transformational leadership theory (Burns, 1978; Bass, 1985; Bass & Avolio, 1994) by showing that the perception of higher levels of transformational leadership by the CEO correlates to higher levels of organizational commitment and stay intentions of employees - two critical outcomes for organizations facing the disengagement or voluntary turnover of employees during scandal-exacerbated decline Findings also show that membership in a business unit involved in scandal reduced individual commitment to the organization.

Title: How entrepreneurs form relationships with other organizations: The securing of investments from venture capital and corporate investors
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Although inter-organizational relationships are important for the success and survival of new organizations, there has been limited research on the strategies that entrepreneurs may use to form such relationships. Building on fine-grained field data from nine Internet security ventures receiving equity investments from venture capitalists and corporate investors, we induct a theoretical framework for the quick and successful formation of inter-organizational relationships. Specifically, we find that entrepreneurs successful in forming relationships: casually date potential partners for several months prior to the anticipated relationship (instead of approaching them seeking a relationship in the near-term), time their pursuit of relationships around proofpoints of progress (instead of around resource needs), motivate potential partners to make a relationship decision by establishing impending credible alternatives (instead of passively waiting for potential partners to make a relationship offer), and allocate their attention only after scrutinizing interest (instead of taking any professed interest at face value). This study contributes to the literature on inter-organizational relationship formation the insights that potential partners often use waiting as a primary uncertainty reducing mechanism to complement network ties and information signals, while entrepreneurs may use preemptive counter-waiting strategies to reduce the burden of this waiting. Accordingly, our findings suggest a duality to social capital that emphasizes both network ties as well as the complementary behaviors necessary to unlock the value of such ties.

Title: Co-evolution of multiple networks
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this paper, we develop a theory of multi network co-evolution. We identify four patterns where two networks can co-evolve. After that we develop hypotheses regarding the centrality of a firm in alliance and scientific coauthorship networks. We test our hypotheses in the US biotechnology industry between 1990 and 2002 using a fixed effects negative binomial regression model. Our results suggest that the scientific and alliance networks co-evolve in a skewed type. As two networks are dominantly substitutable, the co-evolution is biased towards the less costly network - the scientific coauthorship network.

Title: Ngos as multinationals: The implications of diversification
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Multinational nongovernmental organizations (MNGOs) have garnered increased attention within the field of international business primarily as influencers in a tripartite model. However, little is known about MNGOs as international actors in and of themselves. We examine the impact of geographic diversification on performance in MNGOs. Our results indicate that, while increases in the depth of international operations can ultimately result in positive performance, expanding the breadth of the organization produces a negative trend. The interaction effect of combining product with geographic diversification indicates an overall negative effect, but can vary significantly in both shape and direction depending on the type of interaction.

Title: Using strategy tools in practice: An exploration of "technologies of rationality" in use
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Recently there has been much debate about the usefulness of strategic management education and implicitly about strategy tools and frameworks. Yet, this debate is taking place in the absence of detailed knowledge about how, or indeed, whether, managers use the theoretical tools that they learn. This paper addresses this gap by taking a practice perspective to look at how strategy tools are mobilized inside organizations. Using illustrations from three vignettes of strategy tools in use, we explore how an actor's search for rationality and objectivity through the use of tools is actually a political, symbolic and socially interactive process. We provide a conceptual framework for analyzing strategy tools as key mediators of these contextual and political interests. We offer propositions associated with the functions of tools in use, the contextual factors that shape their use and the types of outcomes that can be examined using a practice lens on strategy making.

Title: Take this advice and shove it
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: Across two experiments, we demonstrate that emotional states influence how receptive people are to advice. We focus on incidental emotions, emotions triggered by a prior experience that is irrelevant to the current situation. We find that people who feel incidental gratitude are more trusting and more receptive to advice than are people in a neutral emotional state, and that people in a neutral state are more trusting and more receptive to advice than are people who feel incidental anger. In our setting, greater receptivity to advice increased judgment accuracy. People who felt incidental gratitude were more accurate than were people in a neutral state, and people in a neutral state were more accurate than were people who felt incidental anger. Our results offer insight into how people use advice, and identify conditions under which leaders, policy makers, and advisors may be particularly influential.

Title: Relative wage differences and the career transitions of it professionals
Source title: Academy of Management 2008 Annual Meeting: The Questions We Ask, AOM 2008
Abstract: In this study, we draw upon the utility theory of career mobility to hypothesize the career transition behaviors of IT professionals in response to relative wage differences. We evaluate our hypothesis using survival analysis to analyze longitudinal data on the career moves of IT professionals. As expected, we find that IT professionals respond to relative wage differences by making career transitions; moreover, we find that female IT professionals are more sensitive than male IT professionals to relative wage differences in their career transition behaviors.
